title: eu chief diplomat accused kow towing russia vaccines embarrassing
story: The EU's top diplomat on Friday called for the bloc to turn to Russia to make up its shortfall in vaccine supplies in a humiliating visit to Moscow that drew a sharp rebuke from the United States. Josep Borell was accused of “whitewashing” Vladimir Putin’s regime after failing to free jailed opposition leader Alexei Navalny after a controversial visit that ended with expulsion of three European diplomats.Officials in the US administration believed Mr Borrell got played by the Russians.They regarded his visit as awkward and unnecessary, and felt he should have coordinated better with Washington, especially with the EU-US relations in need of repair and a united front against Moscow vital. In the EU’s latest blunder, the foreign affairs chief urged the independent European Medicines Authority (EMA) to press ahead with the authorisation of the Sputnik jab so it could make up the shortfall in supplies to the bloc.The gaffe came after Ursula von der Leyen, the European Commission president, Friday compared Brexit Britain to a “speedboat” in securing coronavirus vaccines, while likening the EU, which negotiated supplies as a bloc, to a slower “tanker”.For the first time, she also publicly took personal responsibility for threatening to impose a hard border on the island of Ireland during a row over vaccines supplies last Friday.Russia expelled three diplomats from EU members Germany, Poland and Sweden for observing January protests calling for Mr Navalny’s release, which the EU has demanded, after Mr Borrell held a joint press conference with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.Dominic Raab, the Foreign Secretary, said the expulsions proved the Russian government was “turning its back on international law”. France condemned the move while Germany, Poland and Sweden said they could retaliate. “I take the floor to just congratulate Russia for this success, it’s good news for the whole mankind because it means we are going to have more tools to face the pandemic,” Mr Borrell said earlier in Moscow.“It will be good news because as you know we are facing a shortage of vaccines and if there is another course of supply, that is welcome,” he told reporters after Mr Navalny was  jailed for two years and eight months on fraud charges on Tuesday.Meanwhile, Mr Navalny was back in court on separate charges of defaming a Second World War veteran, which could see him jailed for an additional two years.The EU’s foreign affairs chief, who pressed ahead with the meeting despite misgivings from some EU member states was under pressure to at least meet Mr Navalny.There are international moves to impose sanctions on Russia for the jailing of Mr Navalny, which took place after he narrowly survived an August poisoning attempt at the hands of Russian officials. He was arrested on his return home from Germany after recovering.US President Joe Biden on Thursday said America will no longer be rolling over in the face of Russia's aggressive actions and his officials said they would take action over Mr Navalny.A former senior US national security official for Barack Obama, with links to Mr Biden's state department, told The Daily : The optics are not good to have the EU's high representative in Moscow as Navalny is in a glass cage.Bob Seely, Tory vice-chairman of the all-party parliamentary group on Russia, said: I don't know if this is a quid quo pro, but I do think it's surprisingly uncomfortable for a very senior EU leader to be going to Moscow the week of one of its most high profile show trials in the past 15 years.It is bizarre, but it is also not right. Yes the EU has messed up its vaccine policy but to eject your value system straight out of the window so quickly? It's pretty shocking.MEP Sandra Kalniete, a former Latvian foreign minister and EU commissioner, said Mr Borrell had “whitewashed Putin’s regime”.The EU already has sanctions in place against Moscow for the chemical weapons attack on Mr Navalny and the illegal annexation of Crimea from Ukraine.The Spanish diplomat’s embarrassment was compounded when Mr Lavrov accused the EU of being an “unreliable partner” for considering further sanctions.He suggested German Chancellor Angela Merkel was lying when she accused Vladimir Putin of being behind the assassination attempt.An EU diplomat told The , “It was a bad day for the EU. Unfortunately, it was not a good performance by Mr Borrell. He was unprepared.  Mr Lavrov played by his own rules and got everything he wanted.”Mr Borrell said he had told Mr Lavrov to release Mr Navalny and investigate his poisoning in August. Over the last years our relationship has been marked by fundamental differences and lack of trust, he said on the first visit to Russia by a senior envoy since 2017.Mr Lavrov criticised the EU for alleged human rights abuses in Latvia and said that Brussels and Moscow were united in their criticism of the US blockade of Cuba after Mr Borrell admitted the bloc was against the blockade.Mrs Merkel said Germany was prepared to continue sanctions and suggested Berlin would retaliate for the expulsion of its diplomat.She said it was a diplomatic duty to keep open channels of communication with Moscow in a press conference with Emmanuel Macron, who has also called for continued dialogue. With regards to the Navalny affair, I condemn with the greatest firmness from start to finish what has happened” Mr Macron said on Friday. Poland summoned Russia's ambassador and said it would take “appropriate action”. Sweden warned that it reserved the right to an appropriate response.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: government has left britain mercy beijing time running
story: In the end, it wasn’t the airing of forced confessions, or its manifest propaganda on Hong Kong that did for CGTN, the Chinese state broadcaster. It was the little matter of its licence ownership.Ofcom stripped CGTN of that license this week on the basis that the media outlet is a mouthpiece for the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), making it illegal for it to use a UK broadcast license. CGTN is still free to publish online, like anyone else, and it never had a vast UK television audience, but the significance of this move goes beyond that. For one thing, it shows one way in which our norms and rules are simply incompatible with many aspects of the Chinese system. More importantly, it illustrates yet again the need for a government-led strategy to defend our society from CCP interference, rather than continuing with the chaotic and dangerous approach of leaving our institutions and citizens to navigate this quagmire on their own.For now, it looks like we’re on our own. With clockwork predictability, Beijing has denounced Ofcom’s decision and threatened retaliation against the BBC. It’s not surprising if Xi Jinping finds the BBC’s recent China coverage inconvenient. The corporation’s reports in the past month alone include a damning investigation into forced labour in China’s cotton industry and new testimony by survivors of Beijing’s “re-education” camp system in the province of Xinjiang describing systematic rape and torture.What is bizarre about this diplomatic spat, however, is that it has been brought on not by a strategic government decision or even a ministerial gaffe, but simply by a regulator implementing the law. Even Ofcom was itself forced to act by an impeccably researched complaint, put in by a campaign group called Safeguard Defenders, which marshalled all the evidence showing CGTN’s true chain of command. Given the incredible persistence of delusions about Beijing in our civil service and No 10, I’m sure the whole thing is giving them night sweats.If they aren’t sweating, they should be. Again and again, ministers have to be cajoled into accepting the reality that the Sino-British “golden era” instigated by George Osborne is not just over – it never really existed. The Government’s reluctance to accept this truth is the direct cause of the rebellion it suffered recently in Parliament, in which a substantial chunk of its own backbenchers backed a move to link British trade policy to human rights. The wrangling over amendments is still ongoing.This isn’t a normal Tory approach to trade, but it underlines how widespread is the anxiety that, if his MPs allowed it, Boris Johnson would happily let Britain drift into an irreversible and catastrophic embrace with China. Describing the attitude setting in among MPs, one organiser puts it like this: “Until the UK changes its approach, every bill is a China bill.”Piecemeal policy won’t work, either. Take the example of the recent measures on Xinjiang announced with great fanfare by the Foreign Office. Dominic Raab stood up in Parliament and declared that British companies will now have to conduct “appropriate due diligence” on their supply chains to make sure they aren’t using forced labour. If it weren’t so disturbing it would be funny. The World Health Organisation can’t even get unfettered access to a seafood market. What chance does a British clothes retailer have of trundling into Xinjiang and asking its suppliers if they use slaves?What’s more, this is just the end of a very long string. Once you start tugging, anything could happen. Take, a recent report by a company called Horizon Advisory, which took a good, hard look at the Chinese supply chain for polysilicon, an essential material for making solar panels. It found that there is evidence of forced labour use by companies accounting for up to a third of the world’s supply. Maybe we can send in Extinction Rebellion to “due diligence” that one.The same sorts of problems are popping up all over the shop, whether it’s UK academics taking cash from Chinese defence conglomerates, local councils making planning decisions on Chinese nuclear plants or banks like HSBC freezing the assets of Hong Kong dissidents. No 10’s failure to devise a strategy that addresses these issues is fast turning from an embarrassment into a genuine threat to our security.There may be help on the way. This week, the US think tank Atlantic Council published a brilliant essay by an anonymous former government official laying out a detailed framework for how the US should approach China. While Donald Trump woke up Washington to the threat, he was incapable of the hard graft required to devise a strategy, forge bipartisan support and recruit allies. What’s needed, the essay argues, is something equivalent to the 1946 “Long Telegram” that laid out a long-term US strategy for dealing with the Soviet Union. If the US were to lead the way, our Government would surely follow.The key point the essay makes is that the West must develop an infinitely more sophisticated understanding of its own and China’s strengths and weaknesses and of Beijing’s complex internal politics. Following that, we need to agree on red lines and be prepared to defend them, as well as identifying major interests, areas ripe for competition or co-operation and plans for how to implement all of this. If we actually did this hard work, we would probably soon realise that our interests are obvious and easily agreed, and many of the remedies may become clear too.For example, it is broadly a good thing that thousands of Chinese students study at UK universities. It is also clearly a threat to our values if those students are segregated and subject to intense surveillance by Chinese government associations and if the fee income they generate is used to blackmail our universities into suppressing debate on Hong Kong. If the Government devised some policies on this, enforced them and educated universities on the dangers, rather than leaving vice-chancellors to stand or fall alone, Beijing would soon learn we are a society with rules, capable of defending itself.Ultimately, No 10 can choose to be dragged kicking and screaming into a chaotic new era, leaving Britain at the mercy of hostile forces, or it can admit we face a new challenge and get to grips with it. Mr Johnson might not like it, but the world has changed since he rode a Boris bike around Beijing to wild applause in 2012. For now, there is still time to adapt, but it is running out.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: handforth parish council goes global actors line biopic merchandise
story: Most people would struggle to cope with becoming an overnight internet celebrity, with actors lining up to play you in a biopic and authors announcing that they were writing you into their next novel.But Jackie Weaver, the calm convenor of the now infamous Handforth Parish Council meeting, has only one regret – she wishes that she had had her hair done.Millions of people around the world have watched her preside over the meeting which descended into chaos, with councillors trading insults and ultimately being thrown out amid bitter rows over “power grabs” and “bullying”.  The Zoom meeting was held on December 10, but only went viral after it was spotted by an east London teenager who watches local council meetings in his spare time.Shaan, 17, said that his unusual hobby is prompted both by an interest in politics and because “these videos are usually absolutely hilarious – from old councillors struggling to use zoom and amazing arguments, but none have ever matched Handforth”.He sent the clip to a friend who posted it on Twitter and that posting alone has been watched more than 3.4 million times around the world.It begins with an unseen participant muttering “f--- off” before it descends into chaos with two rival factions fighting for attention over the sound of flushing toilets and personal phone calls.Ms Weaver, from the Cheshire Association of Local Councils, had agreed to support the holding of a meeting against a backdrop of “turf wars” at the council.But chairman Brian Tolver refused to recognise its legitimacy, warning: “You have no authority here Jackie Weaver, no authority at all”.There was then silence on the line as she removed him before vice-chair Aled Brewerton, along with an unnamed man sitting next to him, angrily responded: “Read the standing orders! READ THEM AND UNDERSTAND THEM!”When councillor Susan Moore called for civility there were howls of laughter before Mr Brewerton was also removed.There were objections to them being allowed back in as Mr Brewerton’s companion was compared to a laughing hyena.The clip also showed discussion over Mr Tolver’s Zoom username in which he described himself as the “clerk”. Ms Weaver pointed out: “There is no way of stopping him from calling himself clerk. Please refer to me as Britney Spears from now on.In a round of television and radio interviews on Friday, Ms Weaver said that if she had known she would be propelled to overnight fame then “I would have gone and got my hair done”.The 62-year-old pointed out that “99 percent of council meetings are not like that” but warned there is “bullying and bad behaviour in local councils”.If nothing else, what's happened over the last 24 hours has really shown that parish councils are there. It hasn't shown them in their best light, I get that, but we have got elections in May,” she told ITV.The Government seems absolutely committed to holding those elections. Get involved. If you don't think what you saw was right, get in there and change it. That's what I would like to see.There has long been disquiet at the council, and it is understood that the dispute stems from a councillor being expelled for non-attendance.Cllrs Tolver and Brewerton and a third member who was also chucked out of the meeting by Ms Weaver, Cllr Barry Birkhill, were all opposed to that expulsion, it is understood.A letter from the Cheshire East Council's monitoring officer on the council’s website, which is not dated, details multiple complaints about councillors behaviour”, allegations of unlawful conduct and misconceived and wholly inappropriate” claims that elections should not be held.  Cllr Tolver was on Friday night steadfast in his anger. In a statement, he said Ms Weaver's illegal behaviour caused the tensions to rise and said he had never seen a meeting “taken over by an unqualified member of the public like this”.He had been kicked out of an earlier meeting by Ms Weaver and claims her actions were an appalling attack on democratic rights.When Cllr Brewerton was contacted by The  a person understood to be a family member said that the police had been informed and “the truth will out”, but refused to elaborate.The minutes of the meeting and the declared interest of Cllr Brewerton were among the pages which had apparently been removed from the parish council website on Friday.But the anger from some at their new-found fame has not dampened their popularity. One of the councillors is understood to have agreed to sell his story to a tabloid newspaper.The video has now spawned tribute songs, “best of” compilations and even a mock-up documentary.Author and presenter Richard Osman said that he was “busily writing Jackie Weaver into the next Thursday Murder Club novel”.Mugs, t-shirts and hoodies emblazoned with quotes from the meeting and Ms Weavers face were selling online. Bookies were offering odds on her appearing on Strictly Come Dancing or I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out of Here.A parody twitter account joked that Rosemary Shrager would play her in a biopic of her life whilst Dame Julie Walters and Paula Wilcox would play the other female councillors on the call.  Ms Shrager, the chef and TV presenter, responded: “Sign me up”.  It has also put Handforth on the map when the town’s “previous claim to fame was a big M&ampS” neighbouring MP Lucy Powell joked.  But as the world eagerly awaits the adaptation one thing is for sure, the next meeting of Handforth Parish Council will be a sell out, with members of the public around the world already looking up ways they can join.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: royal navy submarine seen gibraltar silent sub sniffer kit track
story: Royal Navy submarines have been fitted with silent ‘sub sniffers’ which can be used to track Russians in the Mediterranean.HMS Talent, one of the Royal Navy’s Trafalgar-class attack submarines, was seen in Gibraltar on Tuesday sporting new equipment on her hull.Experts say the specialised systems are used to hunt other submarines without using sonar, which can easily be detected. The Mediterranean Sea, which can only be accessed through the narrow strait of Gibraltar,  is a body of water very familiar to the Royal Navy. It is an area Russian submarines are known to patrol, along with other Russian navy vessels supporting military action in Syria.As such it could be an ideal testing ground for British submarines fitted with new kit to hunt other submarines. The non-acoustic sensors can pick up tiny radiation signatures from the power plant of enemy submarines as well as small changes in water pressure caused by the passage of a submerged vessel.Richard Scott, naval consultant editor at Jane's, said: “The navy has had non-acoustic sensors - on trials and in service - for about three decades in different forms. Russian submarines in the Cold War were observed with a host of probes coming out of them and they were regarded as having a lead in non-acoustic technology.Soviet submarines tested many types of Wake Object Detection Systems (or ‘System Obnarujenia Kilvaternovo Sleda’ in Russian, and known as SOKS by Nato) from the late 1960s onward. Submarines are most easily located using sound, either coming from inside a hidden boat or ‘bounced’ off the metal hull from a vessel in pursuit. Omnidirectional receivers pick up these SOund Navigation And Ranging (sonar) emissions which are then analysed by highly trained operators.However, advances in submarine technology have made modern boats much quieter and operators have to contend with other underwater sounds such as marine life and even the movement of the water itself making passive systems less reliable. These competing noises are more pronounced in shallow water, such as the Meditteranean Sea and the coast around Britain.Active sonar, whereby a submarine emits noise in the form of a ‘ping’ which is then returned from the hull of a tracked vessel, will give away the presence and likely position of the hunter.   Pete Sandeman, a naval specialist, says experimentation with various non-acoustic methods for detecting submarines has been ongoing since the Cold War. These include sensors that can find tiny chemical or radiation signatures from anti-corrosive coatings flaking off the hull or byproducts from oxygen generation systems.“Wake-detection, that can sense tiny bubbles left behind in the water column by a submarine, appears the most promising line of development,” he told the .“The reason more non-acoustic systems are appearing on submarines now is likely to do with advances in computing and the need to find a new generation of very quiet submarines that are very hard to detect using passive sonar. “The data from the non-acoustic sensor may become much more valuable when processed using powerful artificial intelligence and possibly integrated with the conventional sonar picture,” he said.Control of noise is critical to a submarine’s ability to hide underwaterAll machinery is mounted on rubber and every effort is taken to prevent noise being transmitted to the hull. The main machinery - hundreds of tonnes of equipment - is mounted on a raft and isolated from the hull to keep it quiet. Submariners talk of ‘layers’ in the water, depending on temperature, salinity and distance from land. Sonar can often not penetrate these layers, meaning skilled commanders can use them better to hide their boats. It is thought wake detection systems can help build a picture of where the layers in the water are. A former submariner told the : “There are layers in the water, mainly temperature, although strong salinity layering does happen in places like the Amazon where it comes into the Atlantic. “There’s a real boundary where you move from salt water into fresh, but the main thing is temperature. If there’s a five degree drop across a very narrow piece of water, when sound propagates against that boundary it tends to bounce within that layer.“So if you’re in a layer and somebody has detected you, and you can move to a different layer so the sound is not being propagated, you can lose the detector. “Sound propagates massively in water and if you can get into those boundaries and use them you reduce your detectability.“It’s all about knowing what’s out there and using that to your advantage.”The latest Russian and Chinese submarines are understood to be causing concern in Nato circles, leading to a greater focus on sub-sea activity.The Russian Navy had SOKS fitted on their Sierra and Akula boats but the technology is very complex and it is difficult to achieve consistent results.Now however, with the proliferation of new Russian submarines, the need for something more than passive sonar has become urgent, which is one reason such systems are being looked at again.In 2019 US Navy Rear Admiral William Houston said the Ohio-class submarine USS Florida had deployed to the Meditteranean Sea “to counterbalance the Russian buildup in Syria,” according to The Drive.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: inside uks biggest food charity
story: AdvertorialInside the UKs biggest food charity - which is keeping families fed across BritainBarclays has pledged support to the food redistribution charity FareShare as part of its £m COVID- Community Aid PackagemirrorShareByJemma PattonWilliam Ramsey:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB AdvertorialFareShare is the UK’s largest food redistribution charity One in five children in the UK are currently growing up in a household where food is scarce, and one in four parents skip meals due to lack of money.These stats are no surprise to Kylie Brackstone, Playground Manager at Somerstown Adventure Playground in Portsmouth, which is part of Portsmouth City Council’s Play Youth and Community Service . Before the Coronavirus lockdowns the playground had been feeding children and parents daily. “We’d always have the slow cooker going, especially in the winter, always a stew or a soup, remembers Kylie.Our approach is always very informal, easy access, the children and their parents would know they could help themselves whenever they liked. People then felt secure enough to kind of say ‘I’m struggling this month’ and we could put a little box together for them.”  Although PYC’s kitchens have had to close during lockdowns, they’ve been providing food parcels to families across Portsmouth.Holly Easlick, Health Development Officer for the council, tells us how FareShare – the UK’s largest food redistribution charity – helped: “During the first lockdown FareShare were able to deliver us more food than ever so we were able to get it out to the families who needed it. Kylie stresses how vital this contact with vulnerable families is: “With Covid-, the food was a big thing to help us continue our interaction with the families. Families that struggle with food provision, there are people truly in need.” She adds: “Itaposs also about that weekly interaction. A lot of our families struggle with mental health, so that idea that they knew they could come down every week and get a food package, and also see us, talk to us was one of the most important things.Even though it was just kind of over the gate, we were able to have a conversation and it was a way in to seethere were other ways they were struggling and we could support them.”  FareShare is a network of  independent organisations with more than  warehouses right across the UK. The charity takes food that can’t be sold in shops, either because of packaging errors, short shelf le or over production, and redistribute it through a network of , frontline organisations.The food FareShare redistributes is nourishing and fresh – the same as the food you’d eat at home. Homeless hostels, school breakfast clubs, domestic violence refuges, older people’s lunch clubs, food banks and hospices all depend on FareShare’s help. Ninety per cent of these charities have seen demand reach crisis levels since the pandemic started, and they’re preparing for even more people to find themselves in need this winter. Over the coming months, FareShare will also be delivering food to night shelters and school holiday projects to reach even more people who are struggling. This winter Barclays is working with FareShare to help raise vital funds. With approximately .m people in the UK currently living in food poverty, the amount of food that’s currently wasted is shocking. It’s estimated that a third of all food produced is wasted, at a cost of £b.  FareShare is committed to ensuring that food that would otherwise be wasted gets redistributed with frontline charities and community groups. Barclaysapos £m Covid- Community Aid Package was established to help charities continue to carry out the vital work they do. It’s pledging support to organisations that are helping people affected by the crisis. To support this peak in winter demand, Barclays is pledging to donate £ for every £ you donate to FareShare through the link or text number below, up to £m, until  February. FareShare is able to provide up to four meals with every £ donated – with Barclays your £ means up to  meals for those in need.So to help feed someone this winter, contribute via Barclays by going to fareshare.org.uk barclays or texting GIVE , GIVE  or GIVE  to . Passengers coming into the UK will take both tests during their -day isolation period amid new quarantine measures starting February , reports the . It is also understood the extra rule will be imposed on arrivals from all countries and not just virus hotspots, according to the newspaper. Health Secretary Matt Hancock is expected to announce the plans next week. The measure is aimed predominantly at ing Brits, with arrivals either having PCR kits posted to do at home or given details of their nearest testing centre.When you arrive into the UK you will have to take two tests during your ten-day isolation, a Government source told the Daily Mail. Ministers are discussing extending the school day so that children who have missed out on vital teaching during lockdown can be put up to speed. The Prime minister is being pressed to consider after-school classes that would be run by volunteers, according to The Sun. Education Committee chair Robert Halfon told the paper that ministers were discussing the idea. He said: “We should extend the school day but not necessarily ask teachers to do it. “It could be funded by the catch-up programme and use civil society groups to provide sports or other support. “It would hugely improve the mental health of children — they’ve been locked up so long.” The Tory MP is also calling for education professionals to be drafted in to help kids catch up. Summer holidays are also being targeted as an area which could be changed but this is said to be less likely. In a damning new report, Anne Longfield warned of “missed opportunities” to protect vulnerable young people, with , children - one in  of English teenagers – already falling through gaps in education and social care. Vulnerable children are harder to identy due to the pandemic – with a % drop in referrals to children’s services in November. And with schools closed, bored and lonely children are “increasingly at risk in parks and takeaways, with predators waiting to pounce”, she said.  The majority of councils are failing to get a grip on the problem, with more than seven in councils failing to quanty youth violence in their area, the report found. Only  in  local authorities tracked risk factors linked with exploitation – such as school exclusion, going missing, drug and alcohol abuse or living with a family member convicted of an office.  The vast majority of councilsran drug awareness courses, but only halfreported having a public health drug policy for children and young people.  Ms Longfield said: “Predators who seek to exploit children for financial gain will use sophisticated methods to target, groom and coerce children.   “They are ruthless in their efforts to keep children in their thrall, subjecting them to unspeakable abuse, threats and intimidation. “If intervention comes when children are already entangled in these dangerous enterprises, it is dficult to reach them.” She added: “Tragically, until there is this joined up public health response to gangs that identies and helps all those children at risk as early as possible, teenagers will keep dying on our streets.”

But today it was reported a certication system is being worked on. Tourism chiefs in Greece said UK holidaymakers could be welcomed to its hotspots later this year. Greek Hoteliersapos Federation President Grigoris Tasios told the Times: Greece has long been a favourite holiday destination for the British. “But with the rate of inoculations in the UK largely outpacing all others across Europe and beyond, British travellers will be among the safest to travel here by as early as May. It is often the case that the entry requirements for countries are for vaccines or inoculations, and that is not an uncommon practice,” he told the BBC. We will work with international partners to help facilitate their border arrangements and their immigration arrangements.He added: “The decisions that inidual countries make about their own incoming arrangements is obviously up to them. We are incredibly proud of the speed and the breadth of our vaccination rollout and of course, I think the whole world hopes, that the vaccination programme will be a way of getting back to normality. Travel industry chiefs welcomed the possibility of vaccine visas allowing tourists to head for foreign beaches. An Association of British Travel Agents spokeswoman said: “It is sensible to have the option of some sort of proof of vaccination, because that evidence, alongside testing, is likely to be part of the way to re-opening travel. “Waiting for the full rollout of the vaccination programme to be completed in the UK before people start to travel overseas would mean another summer season lost to the pandemic.“We need a reopening strategy that keeps up with the developing medical situation and with medical understanding, as well as recognising other countries may have dfering policies on how and when they accept vaccinated travellers.” A TUI spokeswoman said: “We welcome any effort to simply the process of travel and enable more people to travel again safely.” Shadow Transport Secretary Jim McMahon said Labour “will look at proposals around helping to allow people to travel safely, but this must be led by the science”. It is critical that this is implemented in a simple way to ensure it is easy for passengers.” Oxford jab is equally good on UK iant The Oxford vaccine is as effective at fighting the more contagious UK iant as the original virus. Findings by the Oxford Vaccines Group offer hope that vaccinations will rapidly reduce cases. The vaccine, estimated to be “high % or %” effective, also prevented severe disease.  Data from  trial participants who tested positive from October to January  was analysed. Although those with the Kent iant had fewer antibodies, Dr June Raine, chief executive of the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency said: “The findings are very reassuring.” Meanwhile the Government has announced a deal with the firm CureVac to reformulate vaccines against emerging iants. Charlie and Olly, both , did it all on the cheap by being DIY-savvy and picking up bargains from antique shops - and the results are super chic.The young couple bought most of the furniture after seeking it out on Facebook Marketplace and in in antique stores, they explained, telling their hordes of social media followers how you can find some incredible pieces in such shops.Meanwhile cheap chain stores Primark, Ikea, Dunelm and The Range provided the rest of the buys as the couple eagerly sought out good bargains. What is your view  Have your say in the comments section The young couple purchased the house in May  and instantly knew it needed some work.They explain on their TikTok and Instagram pages how the put their heads down and laced-up their work boots and got stuck into transforming the place into their perfect pad.And the result is a super luxe, stylish home, which you would hardly tell was decked out with second-hand furniture and cheap buys from the high street chains mentioned above.  The results are clear to see - and have led to the couple building up a huge following online. In just a few months their savvy tips and super stylish home have built up a major fan base as people flock to see how they have done it and gain inspiration. The young couple - both aged  - explained how they did the majority of the renovation work themselves to save cash.  However, they paid a professional plumber and electricians to do the pipes and wiring. Using their previous experience from renovating their first home, they improvised the rest by watching YouTube tutorials and reading online blogs to get tips and see how others have done it. One thing they did allow themselves to splash the cash on was their chosen paint colour. They treated themselves to pots of Stfkey Blue from Farrow and Ball. But the rest was all done on a tight budget. The couple opted to rescue and restore old furniture - giving it a new lease of le. Questions flooded in on their Instagram page as Charlie and Olly reveals to fans how they set up their new home.As for the best buy of the lot - their stunning cream sofa was hailed as the most fabulous find, a bargain from Ikea.As well as all the bargain buys and furniture restoration, they also replaced the entire kitchen and bathroom.  While they tore up the tired old carpets throughout the house and replaced it with lush timber floors and new contemporary tiles. They have been showered with praise by their expanding fan base as people express how impressed they are with the work. One person even said it was one of the nicest houses Iaposve ever seen.  One of the things which stood out for many followers was the stylish blue colour palette. Followers felt is was a nice change from the drab grey homes which are common in the UK. And there will be more to come - as the couple say the home is not finished yet.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dad who was diagnosed with rare liver cancer and has just weeks to live hopes to raise enough cash to fulfil one final wish for his young daughter. Chris Irvine, , from outside Larne, County Antrim, Northern Ireland, is hoping to pay off his mortgage so he can leave the house to four-year-old Naomi. In less than  hours, a fundraising page set up by sister Heather White has raised more than £,, leaving Chris gobsmacked.Mum-of-one Heather, , told BelfastLive she wanted to do what she could to make her dying younger brotheraposs dream come true.It is unbelievable, I had put it up in the frame of mind that anything would help, she said. If you want to help Chrisapos fundraising drive visit the Go Fund Me page by clicking here. In the first couple of hours it went to a grand then two, then three, I just thought it was unbelievable how generous people were and how touched they were. He canapost believe how many people are donating, it is amazing, it has given him a boost which is great because he was so down. Heather admitted her brother, a former Carrick College student, was not in a great place but seeing how much buzz and chit chat has come from the fundraiser his spirits have been raised.  He was thinking about not seeing Naomi going to school, it was heartbreaking, continued the mum of Poppy, aged three. Heather said Naomi is her brotheraposs whole world and said his face when he sees her is unreal. Since she was born all he talks about is Naomi, he is devastated, she added. His daughter was Chrisapos first thought on being diagnosed in  and he worried he wouldnapost be there for her, including missing her wedding and seeing her have kids of her own.  Doing all those little things that he wonapost see, Heather said. Speaking from hospital, former loss prevention officer for Next, Chris said he is desperate to avoid seeing his daughter having to go through the nightmare of renting. It would mean the world to leave something for my daughter as I have fought for my entire le to rise above that mediocrity of renting and getting to that stage of mortgage, which in todayaposs day and age is a nightmare, especially with the current climate of Covid etc, he said.  It would be amazing to leave Naomi with something for the future to build on, especially with it being her first home. The generosity of people has been amazing, I canapost thank people enough, every little bit helps towards the cause, I never thought it would reach such a figure as it has, he added. Sadly, Chris and Heather lost their mum Gillian Naomi Irvine less than three years ago to cancer at the age of . She was first diagnosed in  with cervical cancer after missing a smear test - with the news coming just three months after the death of Heather and brother Samuelaposs dad following a coronary attack. Chris had been feeling run down when his sister chased him down to the GP on his birthday on May ,  after he started vomiting constantly. After an ultrasound that July, it was revealed he had a large mass on his liver before further tests showed it was the rare fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma. It had spread to his lymph nodes which ruled out surgery but he started chemotherapy and was  rounds in when Covid struck last March. The oncologist said donapost be alarmed but we donapost usually see people with your type of cancer, as in they are gone before they even realise they have it, said Heather. Given that it is so rare they donapost have that much research or trails or anything to go with. Chris was admitted to hospital numerous times for infections which stopped the chemotherapy. He started to experience a lot of discomfort and a scan in November  showed the disease had spread to bones in his spine and he had a large fracture causing the pain. Then eight days after his daughteraposs birthday in December he had another scan, this time indicating more spread to the lower and upper part of the spine.

story: NewsHomeowner quoted £, to refit drab bathroom reveals how she did it herself for £Lauren Ham, from South Wales, desperately wanted to give the tired looking bathroom an overhaul in the new family home but was quoted a whooping £, by a professionalmirrorShareCommentsByZara WhelanLorraine King:,  FEB NewsLauren Ham wanted to give the tired looking bathroom an overhaul " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA savvy homeowner has showed how she saved £, by transforming the drab bathroom in her new dream home herself using budget buys. Lauren Ham, from South Wales, desperately wanted to give the tired looking bathroom an overhaul in the new family home she shares with husband David and stepdaughter Ella. But when a professional quoted her £, for a full bathroom re-fit, she decided to do it herself and it cost her just £. The DIY novice, who works as a case management assistant, used supplies from Argos, BQ and Dunelm for the impressive transformation.Lauren, told money-saving community LatestDeals : We moved into our home at the end of August this year in what was the dreariest wettest day in history, or so it felt.It was a very long and stressful process from offer accepted to moving in day, further exacerbated by the restrictions of a national lockdown and the delays moving within a chain can bring. We first saw the house back in March and instantly fell in love. This house is just perfect for us and ticked all of the boxes we had in mind for our dream home together. We have been married three years but this was to be our first and forever home. Despite the property being perfect for the familyaposs needs the couple compromised on one thing - the tiny bathroom. Itaposs a spacious three-bed, three-storey townhouse with a generous sized garden, Lauren said. The only thing that we compromised on was the size of the bathroom which was just over .m by .m. We are fortunate to have a little en suite too, but the bathroom is my sanctuary and I knew I’d struggle with a small one with no natural light. It’s situated right next to the airing cupboard which contains the hot water tank so it gets extremely warm in there. We’d had a few quotes for work which were fairly reasonable, but after spending much more than we had intended on other jobs in the home we just didn’t have the budget left. I accepted it was dropping down the list of priorities and would be something we’d tackle next year. But Lauren soon started on remodelling the bathroom herself using months worth of plans sheaposd drawn up and a colour scheme sheaposd spotted online. For this bathroom, I wanted the tiles to be light and fresh to complement the blue, and chose a pale metallic effect vinyl tile to bounce the light from the spots around the walls, she said. For me, the colour palette elegantly reflected the traditional basin and bath taps. The original suite was in perfect condition and we absolutely loved the traditional features. We only had to change the taps on the basin as the old ones had stopped working when we moved in. I remembered years ago seeing a full wall mirror in a show home bathroom and loved how effective it was. “Having no window here was the perfect opportunity to try it and we are thrilled with the illusion of light and space it offers the room now.  When Lauren pulled up the lino to see what was underneath the job became more demanding. She said: Having no intention to do anything this side of Christmas with the bathroom, the one evening last week I decided to pull up the lino to see what was underneath out of interest. That was my mistake because once I’d done that there was no way it was going back down. Over a period of five days, we stripped the floor, sanded it back and primed it. “We stripped the sealant from the bath using a Stanley kne and white spirit and an awful lot of elbow grease. This was probably the hardest part and something I wouldn’t do myself again in a hurry. It was inches deep under the base of the tiles and back-breaking work. I have to admit, I did cry and wish I’d never started! Once this prep was done I spent some time researching tile paint. I was conscious I’d read so many horror stories and seen countless pictures of tile painting gone wrong, but with the best reviews and lots of handy tips, I settled on this brand and had nothing to lose, or basically no other choice by this point! I scrubbed the tiles with sugar soap, any bumps were sanded back with soft grit sandpaper and we got to work with a foam roller using V Satin White Tile Paint from BQ.  You need to leave exactly six hours between coats, which when you’re impatient, is quite the task. My husband took coat two as I couldn’t summon the wherewithal, and we closed the door on it until the morning. The result was outstanding. This paint dries brilliantly. The coverage was excellent after two coats but we decided on a third to ensure it would be long-lasting. Lauren explained how she managed to keep the cost of creating her dream bathroom space right down. As complete DIY novices working full time we had some help from some very trusted tradespeople to complete some of the other tasks above our skill set, she said. We were originally quoted approximately £, for a re-tile and floor with sealing the bath and sink. The cost to transform the bathroom recently came in at just over £ for paint, flooring, wall art, help from trades for the work we couldn’t do and the large mirror. The bath shelf and bath tray were £ and £, the white soap dispenser was £ and the soap dish was £, all from Dunelm. I bought these before we moved at the beginning of the year as I had this vision that I wanted to create when we could afford it. They do still stock these now.  I feel the wood tones complement the light design and soften the room. The small mirror above the sink was £ from Argos along with the under-sink cabinet which was £, Lauren added. The large mirror we measured and was custom-made by a local glass supplier for £ and delivered for no charge. We fitted it ourselves using mirror adhesive. It dries within  minutes. “The blush towels and flannels we already owned from ASDA, the wall prints were £ for three from Etsy, the wooden frames were £ each from the Frame Company and the green reusable bottles were £. for two from ebay. “The floor was primed underneath with Zinsser BIN Multi-Surface Matt Primer. No underlay was required as the floorboards were chipboard and in perfect condition. We still have most of the tin left, this stuff is wonderful! I’ll be priming everything in future. “The peel and stick vinyl floor tiles were £. a pack from BQ. The wall paint was Dulux Denim Drt Bathroom, and was mixed by Valspar as our local BQ were out of the original brand . It cost £ for one litre. “The woodwork paint cost £ for two litres and was Dulux One Coat Satin White. “The tile paint was V Satin White wall tile and ling paint from BQ, applied with a small foam roller. We used three light coats with six hours of drying time between coats. It cost £ for two litres.”  Lauren is delighted with the finished project which has saved her more than £,. We are thrilled with the final result,” she said. It’s a room we stop to look in every time we walk past. Although small, it feels calming, light and fresh. I love the warmth that wooden accessories lend, I’m a nature girl at heart and love bringing it into my home. All in all our bathroom renovation came in at just over £ for labour, materials and accessories. I think these DIY projects during a time of worldwide pandemic are a tonic for the soul. My husband and I have been fortunate to continue to work mostly throughout but not without financial burdens as le has changed for us all. Lauren has some sage advice for those hoping to undertake a home improvement project of their own.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPeople living in a tiny waterside community blighted by a long-running series of misfortunes feel they are living in a third world village. The Plas Panteidal residential and holiday estate in Gwynedd, North Wales, was once a thriving and absolutely lovely place on the banks of the Dyfi estuary. But now the water supply is contaminated with E coli and unfit for drinking, trees are in danger of falling onto homes, the electricity grid is close to collapse, the access road is marred with potholes and unfit for vehicles, and raw sewage once flowed down a hillside. On top of all of this, the  permanent residents who refuse to leave have to make a six-mile round trip for water or find it by other means - one even collects it from his roof gutter to drink, NorthWalesLive reports. Despite being asked to pay £-a-year in maintenance fees, everyone is forced to shower using spring water tainted by sheep and cattle muck from a muddy farm field. Do you have a similar story  Email webnews@mirror. For the past decade they have been travelling three miles to nearby Aberdyfi and back to stock up on bottles of water. The estate’s water supply originates from a mountain spring below an excrement-covered farm field. The siteaposs faulty sewage treatment plant was fixed after human waste seeped down a hillside, across a road and into the Dyfi estuary, but even now its aeration pumps are not working. Couriers refuse to deliver to the site due to potholes and rubble along the steep and windy access road.Locals are so desperate for proper amenities they are willing to fork out more than £ million of their own money to fix the problems. Some have formed the Plas Panteidal Associationand offered to create a not-for-profit management company to take over the running of the estate after Trehaven Leisure Ltd went into voluntary liquidation last year. The group submitted a bid for £ to liquidators KJ Watkin  Co. Brian Kelly, an Aberdyfi community councillor, said: “When I first moved here  years ago it was an absolutely lovely place to live with a growing and thriving community. “It now looks run down, the utilities are falling into dereliction and people here are getting desperate. “Our biggest worry is  Covid reaches us and we have to self isolate – it will make fetching water very dficult. “We would have to rely on neighbours bringing it to us – or even having to mail order it to the estate.” He said the water supply was confirmed to be contaminated with E coli and cryptosporidium, a parasite which can respiratory and gastrointestinal illness. For much of the past decade public health officials at Gwynedd Council have decreed no one on the estate should use the water for drinking, for brushing teeth, preparing food or cleaning open wounds. Instead the water is used only for showers and flushing toilets.  “The “not fit for consumption or food preparation” notice has now been in place for more than five years.” Retired couple Larry and Jane Simpkin moved to the estate in  in blissful ignorance, but they soon had neighbours banging on their door telling them not to drink the tap water. Larry, a former advanced medical technician with the NHS, and Jane, a former NHS receptionist and health care worker, have had sleepless nights and bouts of anxiety. They make the long trip to get water once a week, filling up seven five-litre bottles every time.Describing the process as degrading, Larry, , said: “People walk past as we’re refilling the bottles.  “They give you a look asto say, aposwhat on earth are you doing apos It’s a very strange feeling. “Sometimes I feel as though we’re living in a third world country. It’s like those adverts you see on TV with charities asking for donations for drinking water projects in African villages: while I realise we’re much better off than them, we have been fetching water for years and we are supposed to be living in a civilised country. “We are like a forgotten community – no one wants to put it right.” John Starbuck has a collection of almost  two-litre bottles neatly stacked on shelves in his bedroom.  The -year-old, who is a lab technician at the local high school, said: “It takes me an hour or two to take them to my friend’s house, fill them up and re-stack them in the bedroom. “I don’t ever regret buying a home here – it is a lovely place to live. I just wish the problems could be sorted. I don’t understand how things were allowed to get to this stage, how we as a community have been allowed to slip through the legislative cracks.” He claims the local electricity grid is close to failure. Wooden junction boxes are rotting away, wires are running through branches and live cables have been exposed to the elements. Plas Panteidal has  properties. Of those, about three quarters are privately owned. Until September last year, the rest belonged to Trehaven Leisure, which has run the site for  years. It went into voluntary liquidation last summer.  About two thirds of the housing stock are holiday lets or kept as second homes, leaving  permanent residents living in about  homes. For about  years private homeowners have battled to force Trehaven Leisure Ltd to upgrade the site’s amenities. Despite being asked to pay £-a-year in maintenance fees, they endured conditions that one holiday review site described as a “reminiscent of a building site” with an “overpowering smell of animals”. Any new owner will have to take on six public health charges issued by Gwynedd Council for breaches in water supply regulations. A further three charges have been levied by Natural Resources Wales for unauthorised discharges from the sewerage treatment plant.  There are more than £, of unpaid electricity bills owed to Scottish Power and at least £, in legal costs. Thataposs before the £. million remedial costs are factored in for new water and sewerage plants, new water storage tanks and an upgraded access road. Cllr Kelly, who chairs the PPA, said: “That doesn’t make it look like an attractive proposition to any buyer. Except of course to the residents with their vested interest in living there safely.” Much to the amazement of residents, other “interested parties” are said to be in the mix to acquire the site. Specialists hired by the PPA to assess the work that needed doing refused to inspect the site’s metal water storage tanks as they were too rusty, liable to collapse and simply too dangerous.  Council officers, MPs and Senedd Members have all visited the site but the impasse remains. Philip Muddiman, director of Trehaven Leisure until it was dissolved, blamed a small cabal of residents for spreading discord, accusing two-thirds of not paying site maintenance fees for at least five years. Instead they have been redirecting fees to a holding fund held by their solicitors for future use, claiming services were being neglected. Mr Muddiman said he felt “sorry” for those residents who carried on paying their fees. He said: “They are up the creek without a paddle at the moment.

title: rough sleepers share lonely reality
story: NewsRough sleepers share lonely reality of homelessness on deserted London streetsRough sleeper hotspots across London where  months ago footfall was plentul are now eerily quiet with the capitals homeless population becoming increasingly isolatedmirrorShareCommentsByOwen SheppardRyan Merrield:,  FEB NewsRorey Ennis, , originally from Birmingham, has been on the streets since he was  " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA rough sleeper in London says he often waits days to speak to anyone with the capitalaposs busy streets now eerily quiet a year into the pandemic. The pavements outside Victoria station and Westminster Cathedral were hotspots for homeless people just  months ago - due to the constant stream of pedestrians. But for the likes of Rorey Ennis, who canapost be trusted in hostels, it means loneliness and little chance of food or spare change. The -year-old, originally from Birmingham, said he survives day-to-day, reports MyLondon. Sat in front of a Pret a Manger beside Victoria’s main entrance on what in normal times would have been a busy Wednesday afternoon , Rorey explains this part of London is now eerily sparse. Are you homeless and sleeping rough  Contact us at webnews@mirror   It is more lonely than it used to be, he says. You spend days waiting to speak to someone. Originally from Birmingham, Mr Ennis has been sleeping rough since I was  years old, and has been in London for four years. I mostly hang around Victoria and Westminster and stayed here through all the lockdowns, he explains.  I usually sleep in my mate’s tent by the cathedral. There are hostels, but I don’t go to them, I can’t be trusted in a property. I’m surviving by just doing it day by day. Sometimes people will pop into Pret to get you something. At .pm over in Piccadilly Circus, a rough sleeper who asks not to be named says he arrived in London from Cardf two weeks ago. “I don’t get any benefits, says the -year-old. I rely on getting my food and money from donations. Today I’ve had a panini and a sausage roll and two coffees. I go to public toilets when I can, but they close at night. Like Mr Ennis, he says there are not many rough sleepers around Piccadilly Circus – an area where heavy footfall once made it an attractive location to pick up donations from passers by.  He continues: There have been outreach people and that’s it… They tell you where to go for housing or where to get food and a tent or clothes. I keep myself to myself and I sometimes see more rough sleepers around Charing Cross station. At night time I’m mostly outside. Since I’ve been in London I’ve been able to sleep in a hostel twice. They’re often full. Asked whether he’s felt scared of catching Covid-, he simply replies: F*** the pandemic.  At about .pm, Boyd Seagal is waiting in The Strand with a dozen other homeless people, including his partner, for a group of volunteers to arrive who will set up tables and lay out free food. The -year-old says: My partner and I have been homeless together in London for about a year. I have moved around a lot but I have been homeless at dferent stages since I was six years old. I left London and carried on to Mansfield and Nottingham and then Chesterfield, Derbyshire and Scotland. Mr Seagal suggests an answer as to why the capital’s historic centre appears to have fewer rough sleepers than might have been expected. Recently my partner and I have been coming to Charing Cross every day, he said. We walk from Wandsworth and all the way back. We have been put in separate rooms in a hostel in Wandsworth for  days. We started there two weeks ago. You get showers and bits and pieces and a chance to do your washing. A study by the charity St Mungo’s and the Greater London Authority shows that the number of people sleeping rough in the borough of Westminster fell markedly between July to September and October to December. The number of rough sleepers counted by outreach workers during the last quarter of the year was , which was  fewer than the previous quarter. This figure was also lower than when the same study was carried out in October to December  - when  rough sleepers were spotted. Petra Salva, from St Mungo’s, said: Since March, our teams in Westminster – in partnership with the local council - have been working round the clock to make sure as many people as possible are provided with accommodation so they are protected from Covid- as well as the other risks associated with being street homeless. And we know from [the data] that a signicant reduction in the number of people sleeping rough in Westminster has been achieved. However, this is not a static issue and there are people still coming to the streets who need and deserve immediate protection and long-term support. Westminster Council currently has more than  supported accommodation beds in use for homeless people, and a further  beds in two assessment centres. The council says it has helped  people into accommodation since March . Councillor Heather Acton, cabinet member for communities, said: Our outreach teams continued to work day and night over the Christmas period and will do so over cold winter spells. They will provide essential support tailored to each inidual finding themselves living on the streets in Westminster. Not only will this help them to access safe accommodation, but also essential mental health, drug and alcohol addiction services, work skills training and ultimately employment. Thus breaking the cycle of rough sleeping, offering long-term solutions rather than quick fixes.

The sheet was discovered by Rosa Beckerton’s husband Peter, , while he was refurbishing an old piece of furniture for a client. It is dated February , , and appears to be written by an -year-old girl imagining the state of the world in . She correctly predicts a huge sht in technology and even forecasts the Zoom revolution. title: stowaway who fell asleep hiding
story: NewsStowaway who fell asleep hiding in plane wheel to UK woke to find pal fell to deathThemba Cabeka, , fled crime-ridden Johannesburg, South Africa, with pal Carlito Vale after five years on the streets, but tragedy struck after they hid in an planes wheel compartmentmirrorShareCommentsByRafi Mauro-BenadyRyan Merrield:,  FEB NewsThemba Cabeka survived an incredible journey to the UK " %, rgba, rgba, url"Our free email newsletter sends you the biggest headlines from news, sport and showbizWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn immigrant who hid in the wheel of a plane in a desperate bid to reach Britain woke up to find his pal had fallen to their death on the approach to Heathrow. Themba Cabeka experienced temperatures of -C and fell partially unconscious due to lack of oxygen during the harrowing , mile trip from Johannesburg, South Africa. The -year-old stowaway was almost killed himself after being thrown on the London airportaposs runaway on landing - resulting in his leg having to be amputated. He was then placed in a coma for six months, reports MyLondon. You can donate to help Themba at his GoFundMe page here. Themba fled crime-ridden Johannesburg in June  along with friend Carlito Vale, dreaming of a better le after sleeping rough for five years. Neither could afford to pay for a flight of visa to the UK and after reading up on aeroplane design, Themba decided the best place to hide would be the space around the wheels. The pair jumped over a fence at the airport and climbed into the wheel compartment of a plane being prepped for flight.Once inside they were left clinging onto two metal bars inside the cavity.  I was not afraid of falling, because I had faith, said Themba. During the flight, the metal bars became so searingly hot he was left with permanent burns. But in the other extreme, as temperatures plummeted, he only had two pairs of jeans and three jackets to keep him warm. Once the wheel compartments had closed, both stowaways found themselves in pitch black darkness for hours, with the deafening noise of engines to listen to, but Themba said he remained relaxed.  I fell asleep because of the lack of oxygen, that’s why I didn’t see my friend when he fell out, he said.Carlitoaposs body was found on a roof below the Heathrow flight path. Recalling their last conversation, Themba said: Carlito said ‘we made it’. I said ‘Of course we made it, man.apos Those were the last words I heard from him, because I passed out. He admitted he thinks about their last conversation daily, and that he struggles to look in the mirror as a result.  Unfortunately, he’s not here, so I’m by myself now. They still haunt me but I have to keep on going. Every time I face the mirror it feels like I’m missing something. Everything is dferent, this isn’t the way it was supposed to go, I think about him so much. Themba only woke up when his body bounced off the tarmac, having fallen out just before the plane reached the runway. I fell out onto the runway and my leg snapped, he said. Lying on the floor, broken and barely conscious, Themba was then apprehended. He said: “I woke up and all I saw was two people shouting ‘He jumped out of the plane!’. They came and arrested me, and took me to the hospital. And from there, because of the lack of oxygen and cold from the flight, I passed out in a coma for six months. A short while after waking up from the coma, he was detained at the immigration detention centre for another six months.  And despite his perilous journey, he was denied asylum but was granted right to remain. He spent a night sleeping rough on the capital’s streets, before staying at a homeless shelter in Elephant and Castle. He was then moved to Liverpool, but claims there were drink and drug paraphernalia everywhere and so he fled and roamed the streets again.Gabriel Frood, , from Crystal Palace, who was studying in Liverpool at the time, saw him sitting in the cold, and stopped for a conversation. He took Themba in and set up a GoFundMe, which has already raised £, of a £, target. Themba insists that despite the trauma, his journey was worth it, but he wouldn’t repeat his trip.

story: Dundee United midfielder Peter Pawlett says they believe in manager Micky Mellon as they head into today’s crucial Premiership clash at Ross County.United are in the midst of an eight-game winless run as they travel north for what could be a pivotal meeting with County in terms of the battle at the bottom.The Staggies are only five points behind the Tangerines in the relegation play-off spot with United, sitting seventh, facing just six games before the split.Pawlett doesn’t believe it’s at the stage where they should be panicking yet and has backed the players and boss Mellon to turn it around.“Every game determines what happens, it#s not a case of us being relegatedwe lose tomorrow – not at all,” the -year-old said.“We don#t look beyond the next game and that#s the best mentality to have as a team.“We believe in each other and we believe in the manager. Today is an opportunity to go and get three points.“We#re new to the league and we just want to build on that and be good.”He continued: “The last three resultshave not been to our standard, of course, but as a team we have to keep looking up the table.“We’re aware of the situation and what’s happening underneath us and the manager’s made that clear but I don’t think anything changes on our behalf.“We keep focused and keep our mentality right and we#ll be ready to take on the challenge of getting three points.“We#re ready for a fight this afternoon, the next three points that are available to us.“That’s all we can affect at this moment in time. title: aberdeen minister appointed moderator of new fife presbytery
story: An Aberdeen minister has been selected as the first moderator of the Church of Scotland’s newest presbytery.Reverend Jane Barron said she is #delighted# to be taking up the role at the Fe Presbytery#s inaugural meeting today, which is being held online due to current Covid- restrictions.Her principal role is to chair meetings of the body which is a merger of the presbyteries of St Andrews, Kirkcaldy and Dunfermline.It is part of a wider reform effort underway across the Church of Scotland. The goal is to reduce the number of Scottish presbyteries, from more than  to around .Ms Barron studied inity at Aberdeen University and trained at Queen’s Cross Church under Reverend Bob Brown, the predecessor of the current minister, Reverend Scott Rennie.She served as a minister at St Machar#s Cathedral in .Three years in the planning, Fe Presbytery is part of a wider reform programme to ensure that the church operates more effectively and efficiently.Ms Barron said: #I#m delighted to be part of a new team commissioned to care, challenge, resource, trust and sustain one another across the three historic areas marked by monarchs, martyrs and economists, and follow Jesus in the st century.#We are working to be freed of outlived ways, put the mission at our very heart # and pray Christ#s invitation #Come, follow me#, recovers anew its edgy, risky, exciting, compassionate love#s call.#Ms Barron lives in Fe and is currently the locum minister at Ceres, Kemback and Springfield churches.Across Scotland, the church is streamlining its presbytery structures to ensure it is lean and fit for growth.The General Assembly of  approved a plan which will see the number of presbyteries in Scotland reduced from  to around .The Presbytery of Aberdeen and Shetland was formed on June , , with around  people tuning in to the first service of the partnership of churches in June last year.Due to social distancing restrictions and the Covid- pandemic, a celebratory service marking the merger of the two presbyteries could not be held in person.Discussions are underway to form a new Presbytery of the north-east of Scotland, which would include Aberdeen and Shetland, part of Moray, Kincardine and Deeside, Gordon, Buchan and Orkney next year.If it goes ahead, it would come to the  General Assembly and be implemented from January .For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. vw, px"

story: Residents of an Aberdeen community have set up a campaign against a proposed energy transition zone.Friends of St Fittick#s Park was originally started following a small, informal group meeting on Zoom and Facebook, before a new steering committee was formed to allow it to be open to all and represent all views.It has launched its own website which includes background material on the history of the energy transition zone proposal, as well as outlines its mission, which is to #focus on the survival of St Fittick#s Park and improve the engagement and experience the local people have with this fantastic natural space#.St Fittick#s Park, which is currently a green space, has been highlighted as an opportunity site for an energy transition zone in the proposed new local development plan, alongside Doonies Farm in a -acre site.Residents have previously called on the council to reconsider the location of the energy transition zone, with the area chosen due to its proximity to the new Aberdeen South Harbour.The group said: #Local people have been angered by the rezoning of the green space to an opportunity sitein the Local Development Plan where development as one of the sites in the Energy Transition Zone adjacent to Aberdeen South Harbour would be favoured.#A similar rezoning would apply to Doonies Farm, another valuable local resource. They are worried that even more land might be threatened as the ETZ’s Feasibility Study identies the southern section of Balnagask golf course as another potential ETZ site and the northern one as part of a proposed Energy Coast all round the Bay of Nigg.#Friends of St Fittick#s Park is encouraging members of the public to join the group, as well as support its activities through raising awareness, letter writing, fundraising and generally helping to protect the park both now and in the future.Group member David Hunter said: #This proposal is a slap in the face for the people of Torry. Aberdeen South Harbour has already deprived us of the Bay of Nigg but residents were promised St. Fittick’s Park would be preserved.#We support the concept of energy transition but destroying a complex wetland ecosystem and a green space which is at the heart of the local community is certainly not the way to go about it.#Meanwhile, the group is also running a photo competition which invites people to enter their pictures highlighting the beauty of the park.It will be offering prizes for the top three entries, as well as a special prize for children under .The first prize will include £ worth of vouchers, the second prize £ worth of vouchers and the third prize £ worth of vouchers, with entry free and the competition running until April .For more information on the Friends of St Fittick#s Park, visit https:saintfittickstorryTo submit a photo for the competition, email saint.fittick.torry@gmailAberdeen City Council was contacted for comment.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. vw, px"

title: return to school expert advice would see many pupils at home until mid april
story: Many children may notto school until mid-Apriladvice from public health and education experts is followed by the Scottish Government.Gaps of three weeks between pupils#to school have been recommended by the government#s advisory sub-group on education and children#s issues.With nursery, P to P and a limited number of senior phase pupils due back in class on February , that would mean the next group ing on March . Three weeks on and schools in the north-east will have broken off for Easter holidays.If, as has been suggested, secondary pupils working towards qualications were next on the priority list, those from P to S could remain at home until at least April  in Aberdeen and Moray and April  in Aberdeenshire.The advisory group has also recommended two-metre distancing between secondary school pupils.Education secretary John Swinney insisted decisions were yet to be made on the next stage of the phasedand that the advice, yet to be considered, was made purely on a clinical and epidemiological basis.Tuesday#s announcement of a phasedfrom February  demonstrated, he said, the government#s commitment to prioritise restoration of face-to-face learning in the move out of lockdown.He said: #Beyond that we do not have a timetable for the restoration of face-to-face learning other than the fact that we want to do it as quickly as is possible.#We will do that informed by the high-quality clinical advice that is available to the government.#On Wednesday we published the advice that I received from the education and children#s advisory group that looks specically from a clinical and epidemiological perspective at the issues we have to think about in relation to the questions of the safety of resuming face-to-face schooling in Scotland.The government will move as quickly as we can to reopen face-to-face schooling and it will have the highest priority within the agenda that we take forward.#Education secretary John Swinney#It#s really clear, well-argued advice and the assurance that I would give is that the government will move as quickly as we can to reopen face-to-face schooling and it will have the highest priority within the agenda that we take forward.#The advisory note to ministers states that decisions on the nature and timing of eachphase will depend on the balance of harms, risks of the new Covid iant and the benefits, risks and needs monitor its impacts, and should be cognisant of the need for stability and sustainability of the approach.#The group suggests phases ofshould be decided on factors including transmission risks, story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall.
