title: nicola-sturgeons-scotland-covid-lockdown-update-latest-rules-explained
story: The "stay at home" message will remain law and non-essential shops will stay closed, along with pubs and restaurants.She also provided an update on Scotlands back-to-school plan, including a phasedfrom February .The decision comes as Covid cases across Scotland have decreased since the start of the year but have still stayed at a high level.Heres what you need to know#:Nicola Sturgeon announced that lockdown will be extended until "at least" the end of February.Updating MSPs in Holyrood on Tuesday, the First Minister said progress had been made in the fight against the virus as a result of compliance with lockdown restrictions.But warned that"continued caution"was needed.Ms Sturgeon also said there could be some "gradual easing"from the start of March.The First Minister added: "If our progress continues, then I am cautiously optimistic that, as more and more people get vaccinated and with the protection of some of the additional measures that I will cover shortly, we may be able to begin looking towards a careful and gradual easing around the start of March."An update on possible easing will be given in two weeks, Ms Sturgeon said.Scotlands schools are to begin reopening on a phased basis from February .Nicola Sturgeon has announced younger childrenwillfull-timeto classrooms as long as progress in suppressing Covid continues.This includes early learning and childcare for those below school age, as well as P-P pupils.Senior school pupils will be allowed toon a part-time basis to complete coursework that is necessary for the completion of national qualications.However, the First Minister said older pupils will only be able toto ensure practical work important to achieving qualications is completed and only between % and % of any schoolrsquos roll should be able to .The First Minister said: "The decisions I am about to outline are intended to give young people, parents and teachers as much notice as possible, but I muststress that they are subject to continued progress in suppressing the virus and will be subject to final confirmation in two weeksrsquo time."Anyone working in schools or childcare settings in Scotland, as well as older pupils, will be routinely tested twice a week, Nicola Sturgeon has said.Travellers coming to Scotland from any country may be asked to quarantine in a hotel, Nicola Sturgeon said.The First Minister said a system of "managed quarantine"would be put in place for anyone arriving directly to Scotland, going further than systems announced in the rest of the UK.Ms Sturgeon told MSPs: "The firm view of the Scottish Government is that in order to minimise the risk of new strains coming into the country, managed quarantine must be much more comprehensive."Ican therefore confirm today that we intend to introduce a managed quarantine requirement for anyone who arrives directly into Scotland, regardless of which country they have come from."The First Minister also said that she could not "unilaterally"impose such restrictions on people landing where in the UK and travelling to Scotland, but hoped the other administrations would work with the Scottish Government to reduce the number of people doing so.Criteria for the pound self-isolation payment offered by the Scottish Government will be widened, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has said.Only a quarter of the applications for the grant in its first two months were accepted by local authorities, leading the Scottish Government to review its conditions.Currently, those eligible for benefits can claim, but the First Minister said: ldquoI can therefore confirm today that we will be extending eligibility for thepound self-isolation payment to everyone on an income below the level of the real living wage.ldquoMore details of this and the other steps we intend taking to support people required to self-isolate will be set out by the Social Security Secretary shortly., people have now received a vaccination in Scotland including % of care home residents and % of the number of over s.% of over -year-olds have received their first dose and the Scottish Government are on track to vaccinate all over -year-olds and all adults who are classed as being clinically vulnerable by the middle of February.Vaccinations of the --year-olds will be this week - year-olds and unpaidcarers will receive their first appointment by the third week of February.Scotland will extend asymptomatic testing to workers in food production and distribution, Nicola Sturgeon has said.Routine testing, similar to that in place for health and care workers, will be brought in ldquoover the course of this month, the First Minister said.Further asymptomatic testing will also be put in place in some local communities, the First Minister said.Seven local authority areas have already had such a scheme confirmed, with plans to be announced for each council in the country by the end of this week.ldquoThis can play a particularly valuable role in communities where prevalence is stubbornly high or starting to rise again, the First Minister said.Nicola Sturgeon announced  new deaths overnight from Covid-as  new positive cases were announced today. This represents .% of the total tests carried out.Ms Sturgeon said that ,patients are currently being treated for confirmed coronavirusin hospitals inScotland.  people are intensive care.The First Minister said that these case numbers are still too high but that the most recent figures "provide further evidence that the lockdown restrictions are working to improve the situation".She added that average daily case numbers have more than halved in the past three weeks and that pressure on the NHS still remains "severe".Ms Sturgeon confirmed five cases of the new South African iant of Covid in Scotland but that these were all linked to travel and not a threat.

title: younger-children-return-school-nursery-month-lockdown-extended
story: Addressing MSPs in the Scottish Parliament, the First Minister said that progress had been made in the fight against coronavirus through the current lockdown but "continued caution" was needed and so the lockdown would be extended by a further two weeks until the end of the month.However, in more positive news, a phasedfor schools in Scotland was confirmed for February  following the mid-term break.The First Minister said that, subject to confirmation on February , all children under school age in early learning and childcare willfrom February .Pupils in Primary  to Primary  will also be allowed back into school from that date, as will those in the senior phase of secondary school.However, the First Minister said that older pupils would only be able toto ensure practical work important to achieving qualications was completed and only between five per cent and eight per cent of any schoolrsquos roll should be able to .The First Minister said: ldquoThe decisions I am about to outline are intended to give young people, parents and teachers as much notice as possible, but I must stress that they are subject to continued progress in suppressing the virus and will be subject to final confirmation in two weeksrsquo time.In her statement, Ms Sturgeon said that ldquocontinued caution was needed over the spread of coronavirus, with a gradual easing of lockdown restrictions possible from the start of March.An update on any lting of restrictions will be given in two weeks time but Ms Sturgeon hinted at a possibleto the levels system that was in place at the end of last year.Meanwhile, travellers coming into Scotland from any country may be asked to quarantine in a hotel, with ldquomanaged quarantine in place for anyone arriving directly into Scotland regardless of the country they have travelled from.Progress has been made in Scotland in the fight against the virus, with the countryrsquos figures decreasing since lockdown measures came into effect,A further  new cases were recorded in the past  hours, as were  deaths among those who had previously tested positive.

title: north-berwick-high-school-headteacher-lauren-rodger-retire-summer
story: Lauren Rodger revealed the news to parents earlier this afternoon. Her last day will be August .A former pupil at the school, she became depute headteacher in  following four years at the University of Aberdeen studying English and completing her teacher training in Manchester.She was previously a volunteer parent helper at her childrenrsquos primary school in Lancashire and later became school governor during her time there.After completing her teacher training and ing to Scotland, she became head of English at St Margaretrsquos School in Edinburgh but, after completing her headship qualication at the University of Edinburgh and  years in the independent sector, she took up her depute role at North Berwick High.Mrs Rodger said: ldquoBy the time I retire, I will have been headteacher at North Berwick High School for eight and a half years, and depute headteacher for seven years before that.ldquoI have loved my time at North Berwick High School: it is a privilege to lead such a wonderful school and to work in partnership with all in our school community.ldquoI will certainly miss everything about North Berwick High School ndash the committed staff team, the supportive parents and carers and, of course, the pupils who are our key focus ndash but it is time for me to move on to the next stage of my le and for someone new to take over the helm and ensure North Berwick High School continues to go from strength to strength.ldquoThere will be time for reflection in the months to come for now, though, I will continue to give of my best as your headteacher.Mrs Rodger added that the reason for her early notice was to give East Lothian Council enough time to carry out the recruitment process for her replacement and allow her to have a ldquocomprehensive handover with the successful candidate during the summer term.

title: council-pressured-abandon-plans-cull-pigeons-dunbar-bridge
story: Plans were revealed last month for a potential cull of the birds before netting would be put in place under the rail bridge on the townrsquos Spott Road to stop the animals from roosting there.Concerns had been raised that birds were swooping from under the bridge and startling drivers, while the animalsrsquo excrement was also creating a slip hazard on the footpath.Now, a political party and a bird control expert have called on the local authority to look again at the options available.Among those calling for a rethink is the Animal Welfare Party.Kay Hamilton, Dowager Duchess of Hamilton, is a member of AWP and said: ldquoThe birds certainly shouldnrsquot be killed.ldquoThis is ridiculous and all out of proportion.ldquoNor should the council be thinking of installing netting, as we know many birds can become trapped in netting and suffer horribly before dying.ldquoAlternative solutions have to be found.Vanessa Hudson, leader of Animal Welfare Party, described moves to kill the birds or install anti-bird netting as ldquocompletely out of step with the times.She said: ldquoItrsquos  and time for us to accept that we share our spaces with wild animals, including pigeons, and humane solutions should be pursued.ldquoIt is an offence to cause unnecessary suffering to an animal, and nets cause nesting and visiting birds the most horric distress and injury before death by hanging, starvation or dehydration.Guy Merchant, of Bird Control Consultancy Services International , told the Courier that carrying out a cull would be ldquoa waste of time and money.Similarly, he suggested that putting netting under the width of the bridge could create other problems, such as trapping live birds, which could then lead to legal issues.Mr Merchant, who previously lived in East Lothian and operates his business from Cambridgeshire, said: ldquoThe very best thing you can do is mesh above the pavement area.ldquoYou completely mesh above the pavement area so you are excluding the birds from either side but leaving the central reservation open.ldquoThat means that the cost of the netting operation is dramatically reduced and, secondly,you kick all the resident birds out from the under the bridge they are going to go to peoplersquos properties in Dunbar and cause a huge nuisance."Mr Merchant said that left the birds to roost and perch in the central reservation of the bridge and their droppings would fall onto the road, rather than the pavement.At a meeting of Dunbar Community Council last month, it was revealed that work under the bridge was due to take place in mid-February.East Lothian Council said that the bridge was lsquohomersquo to ldquohundreds of pigeons which are causing problems for drivers and also fouling the footpath.It was said that work could take up to five days while the underside of the bridge was cleaned and re-netted in a bid to prevent pigeons from roosting there in the future.

title: covid-scotland-new-variant-symptoms-revealed-research
story: Data released by the Office for National Statisticsshow that some symptoms appear to be more commonin those who have tested positive for the new iant, through a survey of , positive tests from people in England.At the daily Covid briefing on Tuesday, Nicola Sturgeon said that the new iant, which is more infectious,now accounts for an estimated % of all new cases in Scotland.The First Minister also told Parliament yesterday that Public Health Scotlandis examining evidence suggesting that there may be an increased risk of hospitalisation of people infected with the new iant.According to research by ONS, loss of taste and smell is less common in the new iant of Covid- - however, it is not non-existent.The following symptoms appear to be more common:In a group of around , people who had the new iant,  per cent said they had a cough, while  per cent said they were fatigued and  per cent experienced main in the muscles.In addition, , per cent had a sore throat.This can be compared to a similar survey conducted with around , people who had the old iant, where just  per cent said they suffered from a cough, with  per cent reporting fatigue.Muscle pain was prominent in  per cent of people, with a sore throat being reported from just  per cent.At the moment,experts say there is no evidence that any of the new iants cause more severe diseasein the vast majority of people who become infected with Covid-.But much like the earlier versions of the coronavirus, the risk of serious illness and death is highest for people who are elderly or have pre-existing health conditions.The UK iant has become the dominant coronavirus iant in Britain and has spread to more than  other countries.And the South African iant has also been found in at least  other countries, including Britain.Gene sequencing has so far uncovered  cases of this iant in the UK, with  of the cases not having any links to foreign travel.

title: road-closure-near-prestonpans-railway-station-planned
story: Works will be carried out under the railway bridge on Johnnie Copes Road, in Prestonpans, from Tuesday to Thursday from pm to am each day.The closure means that people driving from Prestonpans to the car park on the southern side of the station cannot go under the railway bridge and are to use a ersion using the B, A and Tranentrsquos Church Street and Bridge Street before then accessing the car park from the south.Similarly, people coming from the south will be unable to access the car park to the north of the railway line by driving under the bridge on Johnnie Copes Road.

story: The incident, which took place at about pm on Friday, January , on Musselburghrsquos Delta Drive, was described by police as ldquoa disturbance and potential assault.A spokesman for Police Scotland encouraged people to get in touch.He said: ldquoThe adult male was described as a white male in his late s, about ft , wearing a white blue black tracksuit.ldquoOfficers are appealing for anyone who may have witnessed this or who has information in relation to the incident to contact Police Scotland on , quoting incident reference number  of January .ldquoAlternatively, information can be provided anonymously by contacting Crimestoppers on   .

title: womans-search-man-comforted-musselburgh-road-accident-child
story: Victoria Waddell was involved in a collision with a car as she rode her bicycle near her home at Stoneyhill Rise at the age of  on the evening of April , .As she lay trapped underneath the vehicle, a man lay in the rain and held her hand until paramedics and the fire service arrived.ldquoAnother lady ran to get my mum, said Victoria, a former pupil of Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School.Now, she is keen to trace the kind-hearted man who helped her to say ldquothank you.ldquoI have often thought about this gentleman and trying to find him but, being  years old at the time, I didnrsquot put much thought into it back then, she said.Victoria broke her femur and was in traction for several months after the accident, which took place at a junction off Stoneyhill Avenue and Stoneybank Gardens.She said: ldquoI had to use a wheelchair and crutches.ldquoMy humerus was also smashed and all the nerves in my hand were crushed.ldquoThese injuries werenrsquot le-threatening but did result in an end to my passion for dancing and, subsequently, Irsquove had issues later on in le.She said: ldquoI donrsquot have a description of the man who helped me, as I was trapped underneath the car until the fire brigade could come.ldquoThey had to lt the car with airbags at either side until I was able to be freed.Victoria, who is currently awaiting a kidney and pancreas transplant unrelated to the accident, now lives in Edinburgh and her mum still lives in Stoneyhill.Victoria said: ldquoWhen the accident happened, it was one of the biggest things that had happened in my le at that point. I was thrown into a world where there was a lot of changes and uncertainty, which meant that I focused on myself.ldquoAs I got older, I looked back at events in my le that have affected me in some way and, although I donrsquot remember much about the interaction with this man, the feeling of comfort I got from his presence has always stayed with me.ldquoPartly, I wish to contact him in case hersquos ever had curiosity about the little girl he met that night but, of course, to say lsquothank yoursquo for stopping and lying in the rain with me.Contact can be made with Victoria via the Courier by emailing acampbell@eastlothiancourier

title: covid-scotland-many-vaccines-administered
story: The figure contributes to a current total of more than million people in the UK who have received their first dose, marking the biggest inoculation programme in the countrys history.The first dose of a vaccine was administered in Scotland at the beginning of December.Every week, Public Health Scotland releases the latest known data regarding the vaccine rollout in Scotland, allowing us to see, in detail, how many people have received the jag so far.The chart below shows how daily vaccination numbers have changed throughout January. The lowest number of vaccinations were administered on February , while the highest total was February .In relation to the rest of the UK, Scotland has so far given the first dose of the vaccine to .% of its population .England has given the first dose to .% of its population, while Wales and Northern Ireland have covered .% and .% respectively.Usually, we would look to show you the percentage of people in your local authority which has received the vaccination. However, this week, as more and more GPs get involved with the vaccination process, Public Health Scotland say there are currently no details available on the local authority of the , vaccinations that took place in General Practice.Percentage uptake has not been shown due to the large number of unknown local authorities, and we hope to have this data next week.In the meantime, you can check the progress in your health board, including the percentage of the population vaccinated and how many jags have been administered.Weekly data released by PHS means we can now see more detail than ever before regarding the ages sex and JCVI priority groups who have received the vaccine.The two graphs below show vaccinations by both age and sex.More and more information is becoming available regarding the progress of the vaccine in the priority groups laid out by the JCVI.Looking at the dferent vaccinesThere are currently three UK-approved Covid- vaccines Pfizer, AstraZeneca and Moderna.Heres how the rollout of each has progressed in Scotland, and a little information on the available vaccines.Scotland is followingthe priority list determined by the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation .

title: roderick-urquhart-appointed-new-lord-lieutenant-east-lothian
story: Roderick Urquhart, of Samuelston, has been appointed to the role by Her Majesty The Queen.He was previously named a Deputy Lord Lieutenant in March  alongside Pauline Jaffray.The Lord Lieutenant is the Queenrsquos representative in East Lothian. His deputies are there to step in when he is unavailable.Mr Williams retires from the post on March  after eight yearsrsquo service.Lord Lieutenants and their deputies must retire when they reach the age of .Mr Urquhart said of his new role: ldquoIt is a great honour and a privilege to be appointed as Her Majestyrsquos Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian, and to succeed Michael Williams MBE.ldquoMichael has been an inspirational and excellent Lord Lieutenant.ldquoHe has carried out his duties most enthusiastically and diligently, often accompanied by his we Barbara.ldquoHe has given very generously of his time and has been a wonderful source of encouragement and support to many.ldquoWith assistance from our able team of Deputy Lieutenants across the county, I much look forward to continuing and building upon all the good work that Michael has done as Lord Lieutenant.ldquoAs I look ahead, I will continue to acknowledge my good fortune to have grown up and raised our family in East Lothian. It is a wonderful and beautul county.ldquoHere in East Lothian, we are also fortunate to have so many excellent voluntary organisations, businesses and iniduals who do so much to help enhance the quality of le around the county.ldquoThis is hugely appreciated, never more so than in these current very dficult times.ldquoI look forward to playing my part in both inspiring and encouraging the continued good works, but also in recognising the signicant efforts and positive le-changing results which so many iniduals and organisations have achieved for the benefit of others.Mr Urquhart spent his younger years living in Stenton and was educated at Loretto School, Musselburgh. He studied law at university, subsequently joining the family law firm, Urquharts, in Edinburgh in .He is the fourth generation of his family to have worked at the firm, which was established in .A senior partner at the firm since , he is due to retire on March .As well as being a solicitor, Mr Urquhart has sat on ious management and executive committees, including the Society of Writers to Her Majestyrsquos Signet, and the boards of ious private companies and family trusts.In , he was appointed clerk to the governors of Loretto School, a post he held for  years. He worked closely with the chairman of the board of governors, and with the heads and bursar, and was responsible for providing administrative support. He is also a former president of the Lorettonian Society.Mr Urquhart became Writer to the Signet and in  was elected a High Constable and member of the Guard of Honour of Holyroodhouse.His duties include assisting with royal visits to the palace, and with the Lord High Commissionerrsquos Week.He has been a senior office bearer for the past six years he was previously Captain of the Guard.He is a former trustee of Haddington-based Lamp of Lothian Trust, a role he took up in . The trust provides a range of buildings available for community use. He sat on the trust for nine years before retiring.Current Lord Lieutenant Mr Williams said: ldquoI am absolutely delighted by his appointment. He is very much an East Lothian person, born and bred.ldquoHe is very good with people, very articulate and full of enthusiasm, enthusiasm for East Lothian and representing Her Majesty.ldquoI am thrilled and think he is a very good choice and will do a very good job.ldquoIt has been wonderful to have done the job for eight years. It is very disappointing to finish on a bit of a downer [the coronavirus pandemic] but on the other hand I am very happy to be handing over to someone like him.ldquoI am not going anywhere and will be around to help himit is needed.

title: forty-four-flats-planned-unattractive-musselburgh-site
story: Planning consent is being sought from East Lothian Council for the joint venture between Hopefield Partnerships and Places for People to make ldquoa signicant contribution to the affordable housing requirements both locally and nationally.The new development would be built on a brownfield site at Olive Bank Road, which is the current premises of HM Raitt  Sons, a local joiner builder contractor, and Campie Garage, a vehicle repair and maintenance outlet.A design and access statement for the project said: ldquoIt should be noted that  per cent of the  proposed flats will be offered as mid-market rentto meet the urgent need for quality affordable housing locally and contribute to the Scottish Governmentrsquos target of , affordable homes delivered during this Parliament term, with at least , homes for social rent.Hopefield Partnerships, which has been established to work in partnership with others to facilitate funding, building and management of affordable houses in the UK, would build the development.Places for People, which has established an MMR fund to deliver , mid-market rental homes in Scotland, would manage the site after construction.The fund is supported by the Scottish Government via low-cost loan and policy support from the mid-market sector, providing a range of homes for those who are not able to access social housing but for whom the traditional private sector remains out of reach.The design and access statement said: ldquoThe project is an opportunity to turn an existing unattractive commercial site into a carefully considered and attractive new residential development.Thirty-six one and two-bedroom flats would be created in a .-storey block facing Olive Bank Road.Two smaller two-storey blocks on Campie Road would provide eight two-bedroom cottage flats.A shared surface road would provide access to residentsrsquo parking at the rear, with a total of  car parking spaces.Bin stores and a cycle store would also be provided.It is proposed to move the site vehicular access from the existing location on the ldquobusy Olive Bank Road to Campie Road, on the north-east of the site.A path to link the development to the pedestrian walkway to the north is proposed to run through the site, improving connectivity and allowing a safe route to Olive Bank Road to Musselburgh Rugby Club and beyond.

title: musselburgh-rfc-start-centenary-year-200-000-boost
story: A pound, windfall from sportscotlandrsquos Sport Facilities Fund has been welcomed, which, along with grants from other supporters ndash Scottish Rugby, East Lothian Council and the Musselburgh Common Good Fund ndash has allowed the major plan to move forward, with construction expected to get under way this month.Drew Johnston, president of Musselburgh RFC, said: ldquoMusselburgh RFC is excited to embark on this major programme of investment in this, the centenary year of our club.ldquoWe are very grateful to sportscotland not just for the award but for its support and advice as we moved through the planning process.ldquosportscotlandrsquos endorsement has given us the confidence to proceed and enhanced our credibility with other funders who have also come on board to support this initiative.He also highlighted the need to raise more funds at a dficult time amidst the Covid- pandemic.He said: ldquoThe club is still looking to raise more funds to ensure the fit-out of the new and refurbished buildings are top-quality not easy in a pandemic.In total, pound,, from the Sport Facilities Fund will be shared between  projects across Scotland for clubs and communities, schools and education establishments, or performance sport environments.Priority was given to projects with a focus on increasing participation in sport and physical activity amongst young people, women and girls, disabled people, as well as deprived or rural communities.Mairi Gougeon MSP, Minister for Public Health and Sport, said: ldquoI welcome this latest investment from sportscotlandrsquos Sport Facilities Fund, which will make a real dference to people across Scotland.ldquoWe know that being active brings about positive changes beyond participation and can impact positively on people in communities in creating new relationships and being better connected.ldquoThis fund supports projects that seek to create or improve the places where people take part in sport and physical activity.ldquoThis will enable communities to provide more opportunities for participation by removing barriers and increasing access to sport for all.Stewart Harris, chief executive of sportscotland, said: ldquoThe projects receiving funding demonstrate real ambition and commitment to improving the lives of their communities through sport and physical activity.ldquoI am delighted that we can support their work through this investment.ldquoItrsquos important to recognise that, without National Lottery players, this level of investment simply would not be possible so we must say a huge thank you to everyone who has bought a National Lottery ticket.ldquoTheir contribution means that we are able to help clubs and communities achieve their aim of creating the right facilities to develop sport and physical activity in their local area.Projects could apply to sportscotlandrsquos Sport Facilities Fund for awards of up to pound, for capital projects designed to create or improve the places where people take part in sport and physical activity.Since April , sportscotland has invested over pound million of Scottish Government and National Lottery funding to help sports clubs, community groups, local authorities, sportsrsquo governing bodies and other organisations deliver new and upgraded sporting facilities across the country.

title: community-kitchen-knox-academy-team-community-garden
story: Our Community Kitchen is working with Knox Academy Meadowpark to develop a community growing project in the schoolrsquos playground.The new scheme ndash Our Community Garden ndash aims to continue the fight to reduce isolation and loneliness in the community.Elaine Gale, founder of Our Community Kitchen, which is based in nearby Haddington Bowling Club, was excited about the new project.She said: ldquoWe will be planting, growing and cooking food outdoors with pupils and the local community to allow for friendships and connections to develop.ldquoThe project will provide vegetables, fruit and herbs for us to use in the bowling club and for Knox Academy Meadowpark pupils and the wider community.Already, work has started outside the school ndash which is home to pupils with a range of additional support needs ndash on Victoria Road, with wooden decking put in place.Elaine said: ldquoWe will have a greenhouse, a vertical garden and an outdoor kitchen so we can cook what we grow and have demonstrations. We aim to have polytunnels, too.ldquoThere will be lots of dferent activities and collaborative opportunities throughout the year, with the aim of bringing pupils and the wider community together, such as learning about growing our own food, cooking and environmental activities, etc.ldquoThe garden will be accessible on weekends and during the holidays and we can tend to the plants and provide a vital maintenance service during this time.ldquoWe feel this is the right time to be focusing outdoors due to Covid, as it will give us the opportunity to develop this safely.Already, the scheme has drawn support from the community. Members of the public have offered to build planters, with others offering to volunteer and provide advice.The group is also continuing to prepare, cook and deliver hot food across the community to people at home, while working with local GPs on a referral system.Steven Johnson, depute headteacher at Knox Academy, said: ldquoIt is an incredibly exciting project that Irsquom delighted to be helping drive forward, after picking up the reins from Meadowparkrsquos previous deputy headteacher, Charli Prime.ldquoCharli and Elainersquos hard work has got the project up and running and Irsquom really pleased to be able to help push it forward.ldquoIt will make a signicant impact on the lives of isolated and vulnerable people, offering great opportunities to develop skills and provide some much-needed support.ldquoWe would love support to help us develop the facilities, for example, by converting some of our bike shelters to polytunnels, andtherersquos anyone out there who could help us with this or anything  then please get in touch.

title: countys-oldest-resident-ella-vlandy-celebrating-turning-107
story: Ella Vlandy celebrates the big day tomorrow .It is thought she could be the fth oldest person in Scotland.Born in  in Edinburgh, Ella still lives at home in North Berwick.Her family moved to the town when she was about five years old.She has never been married and has no children.During the coronavirus pandemic, a friend and neighbour of Ellarsquos has been checking in on her to ensure all is well.On leaving school, Ella attended physical education college in Dartford, Kent.During her working le, her first job was teaching PE at St Columbarsquos School in Kilmacolm in the west of Scotland.However, most of her working le was teaching PE at Dundee College of Education. Although based in the city, she regularly travelled home to North Berwick.She played tennis and hockey for Scotland, the latter on numerous occasions before and after the Second World War, and took part in the North Berwick tennis tournament in her youth.She has also attended Wimbledon on a number of occasions.Alongside tennis and hockey, Ella was a keen golfer, having being a member of both North Berwick and Gullane Ladiesrsquo Golf Clubs.Nowadays, Ella has swapped sports for cards, playing solitaire and the occasional game of bridge.She also has an interest in the arts and classical music, attending concerts such as the Lammermuir Festival she is also a supporter of Scottish Opera.Lockdown has meant she has missed attending concerts, the local day centre and playing bridge but she enjoys playing solitaire and listening to music on the radio.Ella celebrated her th birthday last year with lunch at The Open Arms Hotel in Dirleton with  of her family and friends.However, due to coronavirus restrictions, plans for a big, special celebration have been put on hold, with those in her social bubble paying her a visit and other friends speaking on the telephone.Michael Williams, East Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant, presented her with birthday cards from the Queen when she turned ,  and , saying to her last year: ldquoIrsquoll see you next year!He described Ella as a ldquoterric, amazing lady and ldquoa great character.While Mr Williams will not be able to present Ella her card in person, he is going to phone her at noon on her birthday and the card will be delivered to her directly.Phone, Zoom and WhatsApp calls have been how Michael has been carrying out most of his duties during the pandemic.He said that ldquoas far as I am aware, Ella was the oldest resident in East Lothian.He joked that, as this would be the fourth card he had presented to her, she might be ldquosick at the sight of him.Mr Williams said he had not presented many cards to residents over the age of .Scotlandrsquos oldest resident is believed to be -year-old Janet Mackay from West Lothian, with the top  oldest Scottish residents all women.

title: haddington-homeowner-says-fence-really-trellis
story: East Lothian Council refused planning permission for the trellis style timber fence during the summer and issued an enforcement notice to the owner of the house on Clerkington Road in Haddington.However, in an appeal to Scottish Ministers, homeowner Kenneth Young insisted that the structure was simply a trellis for climbing plants and did not breach the rules.And he pointed to his neighbourrsquos hedge, which is the same height as the structure and did not require planning permission.The local authority has now withdrawn the enforcement notice due to an ldquoadministration error.However, in a letter to the Scottish Government Reporter, they said: ldquoIt is our intention to amend this error and re-serve this enforcement notice accordingly. Mr Young told the Reporter that the structure, which he referred to as a plant supporting structure, would eventually be completely covered by mature plants.The local authority has a policy of having open front gardens which applies to the Clerkington Road area, although it does allow hedges and fences of a one metre height or less.The councilrsquos planning officer said that the lsquofencersquo was up to two metres high in some places.Mr Young said in his appeal that the structure had been praised by some neighbours.He said: ldquoThe structure we built in our front garden is a trellis to support our evergreen climbing plants.ldquoIt has been built to match our neighboursrsquo hedge height and painted the same colour not tolook out of place while the plants are developing.ldquoThese plants are blooming from early spring to late autumn, whichis good for butterflies,bees and other insects.ldquoLots of neighbours in  commented on how lovely it looked and itwill look beautul once the whole structure is completely covered by matured plants.ldquoThese plants are only one year old and as you can see are pretty big already so it will not belong before the whole structure is completely covered and will look like any other neighbourrsquosgreen hedge.In refusing planning permission, the council said the open front gardens in the Clerkington Road and Burnside area of the town were a ldquodistinctive characteristic feature and allowing the structure would set a precedent.

title: jimmy-mary-thorburn-mark-platinum-wedding-anniversary
story: Jimmy Thorburn, chairman of West Barns Community Council, and his we Mary were married in Dunbar Parish Church in , and their wedding reception got married le off to an interesting start when there was a blackout.Jimmy, , said: ldquoYou could have a power cut at any time and during the dancing there was a blackout one of the guests had come on a motorbike and until we could get the lights back on again he brought his motorbike in and shone the light into the hall so we could keep the dancing going.The couplersquos wedding was even marked in the notices of the Courier then ndash when the paper was called The Haddingtonshire Courier.Jimmy and Mary met on the school bus that took them to their respective schools, when Mary lived in Skateraw and Jimmy stayed in Thornton Glen.But the couple did not get together for another three or four years, when they met again at a local barn dance.After marrying, they first lived in Skateraw but in  moved to West Barns, where they have lived ever since, and where they had four children together -- Carol, who lives in Eyemouth, and Drew, Ian and Alan, who live nearby in Dunbar and West Barns.The couple now also have nine grandchildren and  great grandchildren.And Jimmyrsquos secret to a long and happy marriage ldquoI donrsquot know, he admits. ldquoI couldnrsquot tell you. Wersquove always got on fine. But time flies ndash it doesnrsquot seem that long.

title: inch-capes-cockenzie-substation-construction-set-get-underway
story: Representatives of Inch Cape, which is building the substation to bring energy onshore from its planned offshore wind farm, told a meeting of Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council that work was expected to begin later next year or early in .And they said that the company was encouraging contractors to use East Lothian firms where possible.Speaking to the virtual meeting, they said that using local suppliers was part of their ongoing discussions.They said: ldquoWe are saying to larger contractors where we know there is a supply chain locally we want them to use them as much as is practically possible.Community councillors raised concerns over a lack of plans showing the design progress for the substation.The meeting was shown an old drawing of the footprint of the substation during a presentation updating them on the companyrsquos progress.Bryan Hickman, community council chairperson, pointed to previous public consultations which had provided local ideas for the look of the building, with concerns it would be a ldquobig shed.He told Inch Cape: ldquoWhat we want to see is an architectural statement, not just a big shed.ldquoIt happens in Europe all the time, they seem to design buildings very well while we just put up big shed.Two years ago, Inch Cape held public consultations in Cockenzie and Port Seton and Prestonpans to gather ideas for the design of the shed.However, the community council said that since then there had been no new design plans shown to the group.Inch Cape insisted that there would be more opportunities for feedback, title: paralympic-games-target-powerlifter-micky-yule

title: no-cull-pigeons-railway-bridge-dunbar-council-says
story: More than , people signed a petition against a potential cull on Spott Road.And East Lothian Council has now confirmed that no cull will take place.The council had revealed plans last month for work to be carried out, with netting to be put in place under the bridge.However, the local authority came under pressure from a number of organisations, including the Animal Welfare Group.This afternoon , the council confirmed that work would still go ahead but no pigeons would be culled during the process.: Petition launched in bid to stop pigeon cullWard councillor Norman Hampshire, who agencies, including NatureScot and Scottish SPCA, for taking the time to fully understand the scale of the problem and the proposed solution, which will be widely welcomed by people in Dunbar.Concerns were raised last year about issues involving pigeons roosting under the bridge.Members of the public highlighted that the animals were fouling on the footpath below, which made it slippery and treacherous underfoot.Fears had also been raised that there could be an accident due to the birds swooping out from under the bridge and startling drivers.: Pressure on council to abandon pigeon cull plansAt the townrsquos community council meeting last month, it was confirmed that work would get under way in mid-February.Suggestions of a cull had been met with anger by the Animal Welfare Party and members of the public, with a bird control expert describing a potential cull as ldquoa waste of time and money.Kay Hamilton, Dowager Duchess of Hamilton, is a member of AWP and said: ldquoThe birds certainly shouldnrsquot be killed.ldquoThis is ridiculous and all out of proportion.ldquoNor should the council be thinking of installing netting, as we know many birds can become trapped in netting and suffer horribly before dying.ldquoAlternative solutions have to be found.Members of the public got in touch with East Lothian Council offering to rehome the pigeons.A spokeswoman for the caught following the works.

title: portfolio-sudan-1958-todd-webb
story: IN  the American photographer Todd Webb travelled to Africa to document industry and technology.Commissioned by the United Nations Office of Public Information, Webb photographed the first full election in what was then Togoland , oil rigs in Somaliaand copper mining in Northern Rhodesiaas he visited eight African nations.Webb arrived in the last days of colonialism and, as Aimee Bessire and Erin Hyde Nolan point out in their new book Todd Webb: Outside the Frame, he was very much a white male outsider. But, at times, his photographs contradict his own romantic images of Africa. Perhaps as a result Webb couldnrsquot find anyone interested in publishing a book of his African photographs when he ed to the US. This part of his archive was later lost due to an unscrupulous dealer in the s, only to be rediscovered in .Webb died in , aged  after a hugely successful career. Todd Webb: Outside the Frame is a reminder of one overlooked corner of his career and uses it to examine larger issues of representation.Todd Webb in Africa: Outside the Frame by Aimee Bessire and Erin Hyde Nolan, is published by Thames  Hudson, pound. copy  Todd Webb Archive

title: coronavirus-deniers-dont-believe-covid-exists-sorry-gone-mad
story: For many of us, braced for the next update on the death toll or front line report from an intensive care unit, it is inconceivable that people can think the pandemic is made up or exaggerated. How can anyone doubt the threat this poses, and go around feeling insouciant and safe  At a time when every shop door handle holds the menace of a grenade, such an outlook is unfathomable.Yet it is not as uncommon as you might think. Nor is it linked to intelligence or education, or lack thereof. For whatever reason, baffling though it is to those of us who trust reliable sources of information, there are countless iniduals who are adamant that Covid is either a hoax, a conspiracy, or a fuss about nothing and that the vaccines are intended to wipe us out. Behind all this lie malevolent manipulators, intent on...well, quite what they hope to achieve by terrying or killing us off remains unclear, but the fear remains potent.Astonishingly, not all Covid naysayers come to their senses when they fall victim. Last autumn, as cases in the US soared, there were reports of victims gasping for air in the emergency room, yet still insisting that Covid was fake. That really does take the breath away. ROSEMARY: In praise of JennersSomehow, though, it feels worse that anyone here could also deny it. It is not aswe live in a chaotic or rogue state, where we have been deluged in unchallenged propaganda or starved of reliable information. Nor is that information dficult to access. Indeed, one of the most miserable aspects of the past year has been the dogged coverage of escalating tragedy: footage of mortuaries filled with the dead, of serried ranks of coffins in funeral homes, of the mortally ill saying goodbye to their loved ones from behind oxygen masks.Do Covid deniers never watch, listen or read the news, or do they tune in only to what they want to believe  Certainly, down the rabbit holes of social media it is possible to find yourself in a netherworld, so far from reality you could be a character Alice in Wonderland. Except that Alice kept her wits about her, and never lost her grip on sanity.Alarmingly, as is becoming clear, the pandemic is only the latest of the fault lines opening up between people whose world views lie at opposite ends of a spectrum. We can mock thwarted Trump voters who continue to believe that the election was rigged, despite not an iota of evidence to support that conclusion. Unlike Covid, where the facts are omnipresent, the US election result has been contested without any foothold in reality. Believing the Democrats cheated says more about protestersrsquo state of mind than about what the ballot boxes contained.And yet, their certainty and grievance are real therersquos no denying that. Nor is any of us entirely immune to being manipulated by tricks or lies. You can point to the Brexiteer threats of a tsunami of immigrationwe stayed in the EU as an egregious hood, but many of those who swallowed it whole were already at a point where it merely bolstered their convictions, rather than shaped them.When it comes to medical denial, there is a long and sorry history of refusniks. Just think of John Gummer, obliging his daughter to eat a beef burger on camera to show that there was no danger of Mad Cow Disease . The government similarly played down the dangers of contracting salmonella from eggs, until Edwina Currie spoke up.The more facts and figures we are bombarded with, in our never-sleeping news cycle, the trickier it becomes to find a reasonable position between unquestioning credulity and healthy scepticism. For years it was possible to be a climate change denier, and remain intellectually credible. Now, yoursquore considered nuttyyou still donrsquot get it.What is troubling about those who refuse to believe what is happening around them, despite the evidence of their own eyes, is that it doesnrsquot make sense. It suggests wholesale disparagement, mistrust or terror of those who run the country, a determination to find hidden and sinister motives behind every announcement and regulation.Some deniers, doubtless, have no guiding principles or cosmology whatsoever, and simply prefer to ignore the wider world beyond their walls. In general, though, the level of suspicion and the passion with which untenable beliefs are held are motivated by something far stronger than lack of engagement. Discrediting Covid even when it has you in its grip denouncing global warming, despite the wildfire sweeping over your house, suggest advanced paranoia and a sense of persecution. ROSEMARY: In the footsteps of medievel pilgrimsNor is such an outlook entirely unreasonable at all times. Leadership in many countries is at worst despotic, and at the best, frequently mendacious, opaque, contradictory and evasive. Traditional media outlets deliver news that is properly researched and sourced, yet often biased in tone or emphasis. And the web is awash not just with documented fact but with misinformation that goes largely unchallenged.The fact that anyone can seriously and sustainedly deny Covidrsquos existence is merely the tip of an iceberg wersquove been trying to ignore. It is a shocking demonstration of a breakdown in societal trust and cohesion. When people refuse to acknowledge reality, and choose instead to believe what they want to believe, facts, truth, testimonies, photographic or recorded proof are cast aside as irrelevant.Despite the decline in religion in the West, maybe there is an ongoing hunger to put faith in the unprovable and intangible, an urge for creeds and a community of the likeminded based on unveriable feelings and imaginary connections. Who knows what makes people enter a parallel world to the one beneath our feet. Personally, however, I find the idea that facts and evidence no longer matter even scarier than Covid.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: iain-macwhirter-joanna-cherry-sacked-thinking-women-female
story: The sacking of one of the SNPs most capable and intelligent MPs, Joanna Cherry QC, from her post as justice and home affairs spokesperson is one of those epic moments in politics. Its asTony Blair had sacked Gordon Brown in . It has brought to a head three isions which have shattered the unity of the Scottish National Party: the Salmond affair, the transphobia row and the lack of progress toward independence.Ms Cherry had called for Alex Salmond to be readmitted to the party after he was acquitted of all sex harassment charges last year. This did not endear her to the party leader. Next week, Mr Salmond is scheduled to give evidence to the Holyrood inquiry investigating how the Government came to lose a total of pound, fighting a doomed defence against his judicial review in . There has been a clearing of the decks in advance of this appearance, in which the former leader is expected to blow open the conspiracy he claims led to his downfall.Read more: The jury found him innocent but Alex Salmond is still on trialMs Cherry has also been an inconveniently outspoken supporter of womens rights. Indeed, she may be the first senior politician to be sacked for believing that a woman is an adult human female. She is a lesbian and a feminist who does not accept that womens sex-based rights should be sacriced on the alter of an ideology which denies that sex is binary. In short, she does not believe ldquotranswomen ARE women. For months, Ms Cherry has been the target of vilication, abuse and even death threats from numerous trans activists in and out of the party.This is such an arcane issue, baffling to the vast majority of Scottish voters, that it seems hard to believe it could have come to this. But Nicola Sturgeon has staked her reputation on driving through a new Gender Recognition Act which will allow men to self-identy, legally, as women merely by making a declaration to that effect. Last week the First Minister made a thinly-veiled attack on Ms Cherry in a video accusing her own party of transphobia. Yesterday, amendments to the much-criticised Hate Crime Bill that would have protected ldquogender-critical women like Ms Cherry from prosecution for ldquostirring up hatred were suddenly withdrawn by the Justice Secretary, Humza Yousaf.The key amendment gave freedom of speech protection to ldquodiscussion, criticism or rejection of concepts or beliefs relating to transgender identity. It also protected ldquostating that there are only two sexes and using the words ldquoman and ldquowoman to define a persons sex. The deletion of these amendments could mean that women who object to the presence of natal men in their changing rooms, or in womens sporting events, may in future be committing a criminal offence.The SNP NEC has been trying to enforce a new definition of transphobia in which even the phrase ldquoadult human female would itself be regarded as hate speech. However, it is also the dictionary definition of a woman, andquoting it is to be regarded as transphobia then there might have to be a bonfire of biology textbooks. Universities could have trouble teaching medical students about binary human reproduction.Read more: Dont tell women what makes a woman: they were born that wayMs Cherry is an experienced advocate and the best legal mind in the SNP. She took Boris Johnson to the Supreme Court in  over his prorogation of Parliament and won. In recent months she had been advocating a legal route to independence through court action on Indyref. This is a route which Ms Sturgeon has reportedly endorsed herself. So it might seem perverse to dispense with the services of the only figure in the party with the legal expertise to prosecute it. But in the SNP right now legal expertise appears to be regarded as a threat.These issues have been boiling and roiling beneath the surface of SNP politics for the last two years. The waves of scandal have been lapping around Ms Sturgeons ankles as she tries to deal with the pandemic. Now, rather like Chairman Mao in , she has decided to deal with troublesome opposition by launching a purge, and giving a green light to trans activists in her youth wing, who are highly organised on social media.There is a generational ide in the SNP. Many younger nationalists are zealous advocates of identity politics. Older, analogue politicians, like the former Justice Secretary, Kenny MacAskill tend to side with Mr Salmond and Ms Cherry. The influential Wings Over Scotland blog, penned by the Rev Stuart Campbell, which was essential reading for independence supporters in , is now calling for the resignation of Ms Sturgeon and the ldquowoke legions who are her new praetorian guard.Wings has been assisting the former British diplomat, Craig Murray, in his attempts to disclose details of the alleged conspiracy against Mr Salmond. Mr Murray is in turn defending himself against contempt of court charges relating to the Salmond trial. Another prolic SNP blogger, James Kelly of Scotland Goes Pop, has called on Mr Salmond to launch a new independence party.Like most SNP intellectuals, Mr Kelly had been arguing that it would be senseless to promote ision on the eve of a crucial election which could trigger independence. The SNP lead in the polls indicates a landslide in May. However, he now believes the situation is so dire that the two wings ndash no pun intended ndash can no longer coexist.The truth is that many in the party no longer believe that Ms Sturgeon is serious about delivering independence ndash at least not in any timescale they would regard as acceptable. Thousands have reportedly left in disgust. Ms Sturgeon dominates Scottish opinion polls and the opposition parties are disarray. Her biggest political threat now comes from within her own party.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: mary-portas-frankie-boyle-week-radio

title: lse-independence-report-hidden-sadness-new-report-scotland
story: But I have some thoughts. First: the expertsare going to be subject to what is now known as The Govian Response, or ldquoWhat do experts know anyway  The report will also be subject to the Look Over There! Response, which involves ignoring the central conclusions by talking about something  instead.This, in effect, is what Fiona Hyslop, the Scottish Governmentrsquos Economy Secretary, did when she was presented with the findings. ldquoAs an independent member of the EU, she said, ldquofree from the damage of Brexit, Scotland would be part of the huge single market, which is seven times the size of the UK.But that completely ignores what the LSE report actually said ndash what they call the independence paradox. No one denies that Scotland,it rejoined the EU, would be part of a huge single market, but what Ms Hyslop ignores is that the EU is a much less important trade partner for Scotland than the rest of the UK and would remain so for a long time to come, even after rejoining the EU. MARK SMITH: The dilemma every unionist is about to encounterIt is this fact that sets up the paradox. Yes, rejoining the EU as an independent country would boost trade with the EU, but it would also lead to an increase in trade costs with the rest of the UK. What this means is that, in order for Scotland to be better off inside the EU, independence would have to destroy a sufficiently large share of our trade with the rest of the UK to make the EU Scotlandrsquos most important partner. This is the paradox: for joining the EU to be economically desirable, independence would have to damage our current economy.Sadly, a lot of that would happen naturally, which is the other part of the report that jumps out at you. When neighbouring countries, or regions, or countries in a close union, set up borders between each other, trade between the two starts to decline big time and this is what would inevitably happen to Scotland for reasons that arenrsquot just economic. Look at this bit of the report: ldquoborder costs result not only from economic policies, such as tarfs, but also from cultural and social dferences between nations that reduce the effectiveness of international communication or lead consumers to prefer domestically produced goods and services. MARK SMITH:Why support for independence is up hellip and the three groups of voters who are still resistant to YesThe logic of that is undeniable ndash you put up a fence, itrsquos harder to talk to the guy on the other side and miscommunication develops. The bit about consumers preferring domestically produced goods and services is also disturbing, isnrsquot it  I can see it now: ldquoBuy Scottish! ldquoBuy English! And the English would have much less to lose ndash trade between RUK and Scotland accounts for .% of RUK output compared to % of Scottish output.The SNP would saythat the lost trade with the rest of the UK would be made up by increased trade with the EU ndash just as Brexiteers said lost trade with Europe would be made up by trade with the rest of the world. But the LSE report makes the reality of that clear: the rest of the UK would remain our biggest trading partner for a long time to come, except that, under independence, the trade would be in terminal decline.In a way, I think thatrsquos the hidden sadness of this new report. No doubt, some of the economic damage of independence would be countered by increased trade with the EU, but those cultural, social and personal dferences the report mentions are a dferent matter altogether. How would we deal with those  How would we deal with the fact that a once-close relationship was becoming a little more distant and dficult every day Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: fidelma-cook-lucky-survived-coronavirus-guardian-angel-didnt-desert
story: Before starting work here as a nursing aide, sometimes as early as am, shersquos seen to her two children, one only  months, and left them in the care of either a childminder or her mother.Her husband works similar shts in a security job but it seems they rarely get similar holidays.Some days her tiredness is obvious in her gait feet not lting with a will but few patients would notice that. I do but then I observed her and her colleagues for almost a year and now Irsquom briefly back.Itrsquos am and she stands opposite my bed. lsquoMadame Cook ndash today yoursquore getting up and walking.rsquolsquoLater maybe,rsquo I mumble. lsquoIrsquom so tired ndash I just want to sleep.rsquolsquoNo, the doctor says itrsquos time you were up.rsquoShe goes to the wardrobe and holds up a top and trousers.These rsquo I point to the chair, totally disinterested, lsquoNo, thosersquoll do, the clothes I came in.rsquo:So you dont believe Covid exists  Sorry, have you gone mad She gives me a speculative look and puts the fresh ones back. And wherersquos Mimi rsquo she asks.lsquoSleeping in the wardrobe somewhere,rsquo I tell her.lsquoItrsquos time she was sleeping on your head again.rsquo She eyes the fine cashmere pull-on I usually stick on my now totally bald head instead of Mimi, which is what Irsquove called the wig. Thatrsquos become too much trouble.She finds Mimi and as she helps prepare me with a half-bed bath ndash all dignity and vanity long gone ndash she asks me what it was like at home.I tell her, not missing out on any of the lonely misery or the lack of care.I tell her of the awful, awful emptiness of a house with no dog, no Ceacutesar to love and care for and grumble about ndash no soft paw shuffle from sofa to my side no coat to reach down and gently stroke, feeling the strong heart pulsing.As I do I see his handsome face so clearly and pain of loss twists my insides and of course the tears flow on. But then I see him every day in my mindrsquos eye and fight back the tears.:Country Le with Rosemary Goring: In the footsteps of medieval pilgrimsThis young woman continues to look at me with quiet wisdom as I tell my self-pitying tales.I tell her I miss my freedom to roam my house and parc, handicapped by my weak legs, Zimmer and overwhelming constant fear of falling confined to three rooms not even my own bedroom but the stepless guest room.I miss just grabbing my car keys and roaming.I tell her I miss people and intelligent conversation and yet find it too painful to speak to friends abroad. And I donrsquot know why. Good, good friends who understand more than I do and simply write to say lsquohere at any time ndash when yoursquore ready.rsquoI miss my language and my fluency in it, not this stumbling mish mash I use which seems to be getting worse. I fear the brain radiation has frazzled my French memory ndash selectively cruel given where I am.And I miss my home, yes Las Molieres and what it was when I was. Le has gone and is going from it and living in the moment gets harder each day for there are no moments to give me joy.I miss my fiercely fought for independence above all. I finally stop, consumed by my situation. The wise young eyes look at me. lsquoMadame Cook,rsquo she pronounces. lsquoYoursquove lost your motivation. This is not you and not good and we have to find it again.rsquoShersquos right ndash I have but then Irsquove always been a sprinter, a bolter, not a stayer. Done things quickly, turned the page and on to the next thing. But my thoughts have turned more negative now and the daily world news makes any positivity hard as you all know yourselves.You may not be terminally ill like me but you too have lost your freedom to roam and live in constant fear and loneliness.:Obituary: Captain Sir Tom Moore, who showed quiet fortitude in the face of the pandemicYou too have probably lost your motivation and like me are wondering how the hell to get it back.I just want to feel well and strong again and not so lost and alone. I want, I wanthellip.I want.Just now two of the nurses came in for a quick chat. One brought me a family sized bag of mini-Mars bars as she knows theyrsquore a weakness.Theyrsquore only wearing masks not PPE for Irsquom out of isolation after  days. I am not infectious they say but Irsquod probably still test positive for the virus.So, so far, Irsquove survived it. Irsquom lucky. Myangel didnrsquot desert me after all.Time to stop whining and feeling sorry for myself. I have a feeling that between him and my old soul young aide, my motivation may well be found.And Mimi is sleeping on my head again. Upwards and onwards.

title: symbol-heroism-divided-nation
story: The Leo McKinstry said, with the passing of Captain Tom, a symbol of heroism had been lost.ldquoThe flame may have gone out, but the light of his indomitable spirit remains, illuminating our path through the present crisis, he said. ldquoHis modest dignity touched our hearts. His granite courage inspired our generosity.He said the -year-old had unied the country in lockdown and the huge sum of money he raised for the NHS was part of a rich legacy he leaves behind.ldquoBut his magnicent work should also be marked in a more personal, tangible form, and the most fitting way to do that would be to erect a statue to him, he argued. ldquoGiven his record of selfless service, it is impossible to think of any figure in recent civic le who would be more deserving of such recognition. Through his heroics, he showed us the true meaning of humanity.Martin Kettle said the vaccine roll out was the most signicant achievement over which Boris Johnson has presided since the pandemic began.ldquo It is also an undeniable political boost for Johnson, he said. ldquoWhether it is the proverbial gamechanger is harder to say. After long months of generally negative ratings for Johnsonrsquos handling of Covid, approval for the vaccine rollout soared to over % in late January and looks set to continue.He said the credit for the vaccine, of course, extends far beyond Boris Johnson.ldquoOnly the NHS, with its public service ethos and its reach, could have done this, he added. ldquoThe mind boggles at how a private sector body like Capita or Serco might have approached the task. Politically, though, there is no doubt about the beneficiary ndash it is Johnson.The IndependentAlan Milburn said the pandemic had exposed and exacerbated inequality in the UK.ldquoHealth inequality is but one symptom of a country fractured by income, class, race and gender. Inequality hurts people not just places, he said. ldquo If older people have been on the health frontline of the pandemic, it is the young who seem doomed to suffer the biggest economic and social consequences. More than half of under-s had been furloughed or lost their jobs by last June.He said the question will soon change from how to get the UK out of the pandemic to how to make a better Britain to emerge from it.ldquoWith the government up to its eyes in pandemic crisis management, Keir Starmer should spend these next few weeks and months working out how to make that happen.

title: george-clooney-sewings-new-poster-boy
story: Did you say sewing Correct.
