A legal challenge to the NI Executives restrictions on youth sport has been scheduled for a full hearing next month. Magherafelt-based Stephen Atherton, of John J McNally  Co Solicitors, has taken a judicial review into the restrictions on behalf of an eight-year-old footballer. The decision was taken after the Department conceded Mr Atherton had an arguable case. Signicant progress was made today in our challenge against the continued prohibition on children’s outdoor sport, said Mr Atherton. At the th hour, lawyers acting on behalf of the Department of Health conceded that we have presented an arguable case before the Court and the challenge will now move to a full expedited hearing on March . googletag.cmd.push While pursuing the review, Mr Atherton has again called on the Executive to lt the restrictions on youth sport immediately. Whilst we are obviously delighted at this development, we are acutely aware that the current restrictions imposed by the Executive, at the behest of the Department of Health, are inflicting signicant physical and emotional harm on children, particularly in the absence of school attendance, he said. Accordingly we call on the NI Executive to allow all children toimmediately to the sporting arena, where they will find comfort, challenge and respite in physical exertion and the company of their friends. googletag.cmd.push  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Derrys council has agreed to spend pound, on repairs to the citys oldest sporting facility. The Derry News recently revealed the extent of the repairs needed to the City Baths swimming pool at William Street. The pool, which is owned by Derry City and Strabane District Council, has been closed throughout the lockdown period. When the council carried out a detailed examination of the building, which was opened in , during the lockdown it emerged that major repairs were needed before the pool could be reopened safely to the public. A report carried out by council officials has estimated that the required repairs at the building would cost pound,. googletag.cmd.push The report said that pound, of that money would have to be spent on replacing the swimming pools filtration system and other pipe work. An estimated pound, would be spent on removing and replacing the external plastering on the William Street building. A further pound, would have to be spent on upgrading the internal walls. According to the council report, pound, would be the cost of painting the building, internally and externally. The report stated that the City Baths, which has been home to the City of Derry Swimming Club for many years, would have to be closed for nine months to allow the repair works to be carried out. googletag.cmd.push The report was discussed in confidential business at the councils monthly meeting last week. It was agreed at the meeting that the money should be spent on the City Baths repairs. A spokesperson for the council confirmed that a decision to approve an investment in extensive essential capital works at the City Baths by the Health and Community Committee was ratied at the full council meeting. There is no timescale yet as to when the repair work at the local swimming pool will begin.      --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Poundland will open an extension at its store in Lisnagelvin Shopping Centre in Derry on Monday. The extension increases the floor space by more than half, taking it to , square feet. Six new dog waste bins are to be installed at Ebrington Square in Derry. The planned installation of the new bins emerged at a meeting this week of Derry City and Strabane District Councils Planning Committee. Concerns were raised at a recent meeting of the committee about the increased level of waste at Ebrington Square during the lockdown period. In response, the committee wrote to the Executive Office which is in charge of the management of Ebrington Square. Sinn Fein councillor Christopher Jackson, who chairs the planning committee, said the Executive Office had written back about the issue. He said the Executive Office had asked takeaway businesses operating at Ebrington Square to use recyclable materials where possible. googletag.cmd.push The Executive Office said they also planned to install waste bins for recyclable items at Ebrington Square which, Cllr Jackson said, was a first for the area. He welcomed the plans to do more to address the waste issues which have come about as a result of the increase in the number of people visiting the area. googletag.cmd.push  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Watty Grahams Glen led the tributes to their oldest living player Freddie Joe Tohill who was buried on Monday after passing away on Saturday, aged . Freddie Joe, a teetotaller all his days, had a long playing career with the Wattys, playing until his mid-s and also served on the clubs committee. He had a terric interest in football, not only of Glen and Derry, but further afield and attended All-Ireland finals in Croke Park. “Watty Grahams are saddened to learn of the passing of Freddie Joe Tohill,” read a statement on the clubs Facebook page. Glen committee members at the  All-Ireland Final in Dublin : Danny McKenna, Pat Convery, Freddie Joe Tohill and Frances Kielt googletag.cmd.push “Freddie Joe was our oldest living past player. He served us well, both as a player and Club Officer. Condolences to his family at this sad time. A le very well lived. Ar dheis Deacute go raibh a anam uasal.” The comments below the message tells the story of his legacy. One word cropped up time and time again – gentleman. At Mondays requiem mass, streamed live from St Patricks Glen, Parish Priest Father Paddy Doherty spoke of the many many people who wouldve been present, only for the current Covid- restrictions. Fr Doherty also thanked those who sang. It was fitting, as Freddie was a great singer and a member of the choir. googletag.cmd.push His talents didnt end there, he had a tremendous interest in local drama. He was regularly involved in plays and pantomimes when Magheras National Hall was in its pomp. Freddie Joe was the beloved husband of the late Annie Elizabeth and loving father of Terence, Fred, Anne and Maureen, and a dear brother of Noel and the late Sean, Colm and Maureen. He was brought up in Maghera, at the corner of Main Street and the Coleraine Road. There, his father Fred had a butchers shop and Freddie Joe, with his brother Sean, learned their trade. Freddie Joe then took over the shop, which was later moved to Upper Main Street, on the site of Eurospar, where it stood until its closure.     He was very popular in the community and among the other business owners in the town. On the field, in the shop and throughout the community, Freddie Joe was popular. title: Ciara comes out top
story: PORTAFERRYrsquoS Ciara Mageean is celebrating after picking up an international award in recognition of her achievements in .She was named the Her Sport Athlete of the Year in  after breaking three Irish records and cemented her status as one of the finest middle-distance runners in the world.Thousands of votes were cast, with Ciara coming out on top against a star-studded list of Irish sportswomen.During  the  year-old broke the m Irish Indoor record, became the first Irish woman to dip under the two-minute mark in the m, and broke Sonia OrsquoSullivanrsquos  year-old m record.Ciara said she was honoured to receive the award.ldquoThank you so much to everyone who voted for me. I am so chuffed, thank you, she remarked afterwards.The award made up for a disappointing weekend on the track for Ciara mdash she finished last in a m race at Fridayrsquos World Indoor Tour meeting in Karlsruhe, Germany.Sitting in third place at the m mark, she fell away over the next two laps and eventually crossed the line in .., nearly  seconds slower than her personal best.Ciara had been competing following the sad news that her ex-coach Jerry Kiernan had passed away suddenly last week.Ciara said that did affect her performance. Writing on her Twitter account she commented: ldquoJerryrsquos passing took more from me than I anticipated.ldquoIt was a disappointing performance after a very tough week. I never like excuses, but I know that I am in good shape.Ciara is preparing for the European Indoor Championships in March, as well as counting down towards the Tokyo Olympic Games..prettyPhoto

title: Ciara discusses life in RTE show with former Irish president
story: A FORMER Irish president has travelled to the heart of St Patrickrsquos country as part of an RTE programme featuring a St Patrick Centre guide and a champion runner.Mary McAleese has interviewed European bronze medallist Ciara Mageean from Portaferry, on a walk along the Co Down coast with Duane Fitzsimons, a guide from the centre in Downpatrick.Their coastal adventure mdash via Ballyhornan towards St Patrickrsquos Well at Sheepland mdash is being broadcast this Friday as part of the RTE series All Walks of Le, presented by the former Irish president.In the programme, Mrs McAleese and Ciara are greeted by Duane, who has his own historic links with the area going back generations.The Ardglass man is descended from an Anglo-Norman Savage family of the Ards, who arrived in twelfth century under the leadership of Norman conquerer John de Courcy.Mr Fitzsimons, a keen historian and walker, pointed the programme to the unique coastal route after RTE contacted him through a connection with the Walk NI website. Mr Fitzsimons is well-known for his walking tours in this area.ldquoI came up with the idea of doing the coastal path and following the pilgrim path to the holy well, he said.ldquoThe reason we did that was because of the outstanding natural beauty that is there. It is a really undiscovered kind of gem in the whole of the island in terms of the natural beauty.As part of the filming, Duane met the former president and Ciara for a picnic and a chat. ldquoWe staged the picnic at Ballyhornan with an upturned boat and our lunch on top of it, he explained.He added that it was a delight to meet the former president.ldquoMary McAleese was really quite personable and willing to get to know a bit about me and also about the whole area.The programmes takes guests to dferent locations in Ireland to talk about their spiritual journey through le.It is the second film in the current series to showcase the beauty of the Co Down countryside.The first film aired last month and featured the former president with Dundrum-born comedian Patrick Kielty on a walk through St Patrickrsquos Way in the Mournes.Mr Kielty was asked about his faith in God and replied: ldquoIf you are not going to believe in God walking up the Mourne Mountains, when are you going to believe in Him Former Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has also taken part in the series this year. Dr Tim Campbell, director of the St Patrick Centre, said he was delighted the focus was on Saint Patrickrsquos Way.He is looking forward to the new season of Camino-style walks being offered from April post lockdown.ldquoWe are really excited about the new coastal route we are offering which will be led in turns by guides Martina Purdy and Elaine Kelly, he said.ldquoThe walk some of the most beautul coast line on the island and features views of the Isle of Man on a clear day.ldquoThe well itself is amazing and the walk also takes in the historic church ruin at Ardtole. Details of all our walks can be found on www.saintpatrickcentre.Mr Fitzsimons will lead a guided six-mile walk which includes a visit to a pre-Christian burial site, a journey to the place where St Patrick landed in AD and a trip to St Tassachrsquos Church, Raholp. It leaves Saint Patrickrsquos Centre on April .All Walks of Le is on RTE One this Friday at .pm..prettyPhoto

title: Dissidents linked to mortar rocket
story: DISSIDENT republicans are being linked with the discovery of a viable rocket grenade near Seaforde last weekend.The discovery of the suspicious device was made by a member of the public last Saturday which resulted in a major security operation swinging into action and the closure of the main Newcastle Road. A number of residents were also forced to leave their homes.The mortar was discovered at the side of a busy road close to the entrance to Tievenadarragh Wood and after it was inspected by Army Technical Officers and declared safe, the device was taken away for detailed forensic examination.A number of politicians have expressed concern that this is the third device of its kind linked to dissident republicans which has been discovered in the area over the past two years.Previous devices linked to the terror group have been discovered just a few miles from Seaforde at the Priestrsquos Road and Drumcaw Road near Clough.PSNI District Commander, Superintendent Norman Haslett, has confirmed that the device discovered at the Newcastle Road was a suspected component part of a mortar, but did not contain any explosives.He said that while it was too early to attribute ownership to any particular grouping, he believed that dissident republican terrorists were responsible.Mr Haslett said the matter remained under investigation and appealed for anyone who can assist police with their enquiries to get in contact with them.Politicians have roundly condemned those responsible for leaving the device at the side of one of the districtrsquos most busiest roads.South Down SDLP MLA Colin McGrath, Sinn Fein MLA Emma Rogan and Slieve Croob Ulster Unionist councillor Alan Lewis, said there was no justication for the actions of those responsible.Mr McGrath described the discovery of the mortar component as ldquovery concerning and said the repercussions of the weekend incident could have been devastating.He declared: Such devices are a thing of our past and have no place in our modern country. The inconvenience and impact of this incident on the local community will be considerable and I condemn those that placed that device.ldquoThe fact that the Newcastle Road had to be closed for a number of hours last Saturday evening is both infuriating and depressing. Infuriating because some iniduals wish to bring violence upon us and depressing at the thought of what might have come to pass,the device had not been found and dealt with.Mr McGrath, who thanked the emergency services for their swt response to the security alert, said those responsible ldquohave nothing to offer our society and are utterly contemptible.Condemning those responsible for the ldquodisruptive security alert, Ms Rogan described what happened as ldquoreckless activity.She declared: ldquoThe arearsquos district police commander has confirmed that a component part of a mortar device was found which could have been more sinister. Whoever was responsible for leaving this device and causing this disruption has shown complete disregard for the local community. There can be no justication for this type of reckless activity and those responsible need to cease these futile acts.Cllr Lewis said leaving a device at the side of the road ldquodemonstrates the stupidity of those responsible.He declared: ldquoTerrorism always finds a cause to attach itself and those seeking to ignite chaos and mayhem should reflect on the long-term realities of their aims. Tit-for-tat violence reenergises age-old conflict and no one will benefit from rising tension and public disorder.ldquoThose responsible are Neanderthals, plastic soldiers with romantic fantasies of days gone by. Just what are they trying to achieve Cllr Lewis said residents were ldquorightly alarmed at what happened last weekend, confirming that he is angry that a third mortar-type device has now been found in this part of the district in the past two years.He added: ldquoIt is time for the police to act. I want to see searches, investigations and arrests. I fear that dissident republicans are armed and dangerous and weapons in the hands of those who lack intelligence could quite possibly result in the loss of le.ldquoThis is  not  and those behind this incident need to pack up and go home. If they canrsquot win elections it demonstrates that the community doesnrsquot want nor support them and I question what mindless criminals behind this behaviour have to offer society.Anyone who can assist police with their enquiries is asked to get in touch using the non-emergency  number, quoting reference    .Information can also be provided online at http:www.psni.police.uk makeareport  or by using the confidential Crimestoppers number  ..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick’s Conor makes move to Glens
story: DOWNPATRICKrsquoS Conor McMenamin has made the cross-city switch from Irish Premiership side Cltonville to Belfast rivals Glentoran.The -year old midfielder is back at the Oval for a second spell after a move to Warrenpoint Town followed by over two years at Solitude.Glentoran striker Paul OrsquoNeill is moving to Cltionville as part of the deal.Glentoran manager Mick McDermott said was delighted to secure McMenaminrsquos capture.ldquoWe are excited to secure the signature of Conor, arguably the hottest property in the league at this time, he remarked.ldquoI have always said that we will be interested when quality players become available. Conor clearly fits that profile and we acted swtly to secure a deal.ldquoConor had multiple offers during this window, and it shows the direction Glentoran are headed when we can attract a player of this quality.McMenamin was delighted to get the move over the line: ldquoTo be honest, the deal to go to Larne was done. I agreed to sign for them, but the phone kept ringing and I knew it was Glentoran.ldquoThen Paddy McLaughlinrang me and said will you just pick the phone up to Glentoran. To be honest, what they offered me, I just couldnrsquot turn it down.ldquoIrsquove got a wee girl and driving to Larne every day was a bit longer. I just took everything into consideration and as the day went on, I edged towards Glentoran.McMenamin has said that the growing professionalism of the Irish League can cause problems for the players and teams who are part-time.ldquoIt is not ideal when you are up against full-time players. They can prepare for games all day, he remarked.ldquoI might be going straight from work up the road to a game, grabbing a sandwich on the way. The full-time players might be able to prepare and rest all day ahead of the game. So that can make things dficult.McMenamin says he feels lucky to be able to play football safely doing so, despite Covid-.ldquoIrsquove been privileged to play football. Some players I know said about feeling unsafe. But my local friends playing amateur football, they canrsquot wait to get back. They miss it, he saidldquoWersquore in a privileged position. I feel safe coming to training and playing. I was never one for wanting the game to stop.He added: I canrsquot say I have visited a ground this season where I felt unsafe. Every step is being taken to ensure they keep their grounds as safe as possible against Covid-..prettyPhoto

title: Dunleath Park redevelopment important step for Downpatrick
story: A FRESH appeal has been issued to Newry, Mourne and Down Council to ensure that the redevelopment of Downpatrickrsquos Dunleath Park is one of its top priorities.It comes after a recent failed attempt by local authority officials to have the issue dealt with by Downpatrick area councillors, not a dedicated working party.Dunleath Park mdash which is used extensively by the Downpatrick Youth Football League and other sports clubs mdash has been considered as the potential site for a sports hub in the town, with council officials currently investigating the potential for a walking trail in the park as well.Councillors believe that the huge town centre area offers signicant development potential and that its future should be accorded the same priority as the Albert Basin site in Newry where a working group has been created by the local council to oversee the progress of this particular scheme.A proposal for a working group, comprising Downpatrick councillors and local authority officials to be set up to oversee the redevelopment of Dunleath Park, was agreed at Monday nightrsquos monthly meeting of the local authority.The decision has been welcomed by Cllr Gareth Sharvin, who said that exploiting the parkrsquos full potential should be a top priority for the council.ldquoThere is a need to breathe new le back into Downpatrick and develop local sports and recreational facilities for the people across Downpatrick, Lecale, Rowallane and further afield, he said.ldquoIt is important that proposals for the future of Dunleath Park is an important pillar of the local authorityrsquos programme of work.The importance of Dunleath cannot be understated. The location has been a vital area for sports for decades within district, but there has been underinvestment for some time, leaving our area behind other council areas.Cllr Sharvin, who tabled an original proposal for a dedicated working group to oversee the development of the park, said the intention is for council officials to carry out investigative work to identy what areas of Dunleath can be developed, given flood plain issues in the area.He explained that once this investigative work is completed, it would enable the working group to identy what facilities can be accommodated in the areas identied.Cllr Sharvin said the working group would be able to advance the project to the business case stage for capital spend to be committed, paving the way for work to start.ldquoThis is the process the council undertakes for any project but, disappointingly, the council did not seem to want to follow its own process used for other projects, he continued.ldquoAt the recent Active and Healthy Communities Committee the item was discussed for a second time in two months, with councillors rejecting a recommendation not to set up a working group.Cllr Sharvin confirmed that Downpatrick area councillors will meet shortly with senior council officers to identy recommendations for the future development of Dunleath Park which the Active and Healthy Communities Committee can consider.He added: ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down Council cannot under value the importance of Dunleath to Downpatrick.ldquoThe area provides a great opportunity to really develop the area through walking trails around the perimeter of the site, upgrade the existing facilities and identy new ones that can be delivered.ldquoCovid has taught us all the importance of getting out and being active and Downpatrick town centre does not have a town park that provides all of that..prettyPhoto

title: Fishing communities urged to apply for European funding
story: AN appeal has been issued to people in the Ardglass area to make funding bids under the South East Area Fisheries Local Action Groupprogramme.Applications for the latest funding round must be submitted by the end of next month with work on successful schemes completed by October next year.Funding is being made to fishing communities under the European Maritime Fisheries Fund to support a broad range of projects that focus on promoting economic growth, job creation and supporting labour mobility in coastal and inland communities.Proposed projects must be in the Ardglass area with applicants able to demonstrate how schemes will impact on those who rely upon the fishing industry.Key themes of the funding programme include adding value to fishery and aquaculture products and supporting their ersication and promotion, creating opportunities for lelong learning, attracting young people into fisheries, aquaculture and maritime related careers and activities.The funding programme also aims to promote social well-being and cultural heritage and developing and enhancing environmental assets of fisheries areas.Cllr Dermot Curran mdash who lives in Ardglass mdash says the funding aims to help make a dference and deliver socio-economic benefits to the communities along the Co Down coastline that continue to rely heavily on the fishing industry.He says he is pleased that people and businesses in the Ardglass, Kilkeel and Portavogie areas are being given an opportunity to benefit from the funding.ldquoThe programme provides an opportunity to strengthen and ersy the economy, making a real dference to their respective communities through developing and delivering innovative projects, he continued.There are currently plans to regenerate the port in Ardglass and thevillagersquos harbour development group has drawn up a series of proposals to help kick-start economic regeneration, one of which includes dredging the harbour.There are also plans to upgrade berthing facilities and relocate trawlers to the an area known locally as the Saw Pit at the harbour.Cllr Curran said he was keen to see investment provided to secure the future of the three Co Down ports which are responsible for sustaining signicant jobs on land and at sea.He added: ldquoThe needs of local fishermen and their dependent communities is vitally important.The needs of the fishing community and the challenges it faces must be front and centre.One-to-one virtual workshops are available for the SEAFLAG programme including help with procurement, application form guidance and registration.Projects seeking financial support should be based in the Ardglass, Kilkeel and Portavogie or surrounding areas and demonstrate how they will impact on fishing dependent communities and a reminder issued that applications submitted after March  may not be accepted.Anyone requiring assistance is asked to contact SEAFLAG on   or email sea@flagnmandd.org to arrange a meeting. Further details are also available at www.seaflag..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C January 31%2C 2001
story: BALLYNAHINCH ndash A highly respected cross-community group has this week warned politicians not to use Ballynahinch as an electoral battle ground.The warning by the Ballynahinch, Drumaness and Spa Community Association comes amid increasing speculation that two major elections are likely to be held within the next few months.The local group has warned that rather than making a political issue out of Ballynahinch, politicians should be focusing their efforts on healing ision.Its public stand is likely to be applauded by community groups across the district as the area prepares for what is likely to be one of the most intensive ever election battles, with local government and Westminster polls possibly just months away.Major political battle lines are already being drawn in ious areas, including Ballynahinch, and this is one of the key reasons why the local Association says it has taken the unprecedented step of issuing its public statement.It is urging politicians on all sides of the political spectrum to work with local communities in a bid to create a better society.The Association is concerned at recent comments by Sinn Fein representatives and says it has no desire to see the undermining of efforts of people working hard to reduce sectarian tensions. It also warns it will not stand by and see peoplersquos lives put at risk by comments designed to advance particular political causes.KILLINCHY ndash Local politicians have expressed their concern about the future of the Carpets International factory in Killinchy.The plant which employs  people, many of them from Down District, faces an uncertain future after its American owners revealed its plans to downsize and restructure its operation across the United Kingdom.Fears are growing that both the Killinchy plant, and its sister factory in Donaghadee, could be forced to close their doors, with the loss of  jobs. Speculation that the plant could close is increasing because of the American firmrsquos continued refusal to say whether or not the local plants will be spared from the axe.DRUMAROAD ndash The ongoing saga surrounding the attempted demolition of Drumaroad parish hall will be in the High Court again on Friday.At the hearing Fr John Moley, PP, will attempt to have lted an injunction preventing the demolition of the hall but local residents have said they will fight the move.The case had been listed for hearing last Friday but on Wednesday Fr Moley submitted an affidavit outlining his reasons for proposing the demolition. Mr Justice Kerr decided to adjourn the case to allow detailed consideration of the affidavit.The injunction was granted before Christmas to parishioner, Mrs Stephanie Doherty, and prevents Fr Moley proceeding with his plan too demolish the former dance hall.But residents have warned thatthe injunction is lted they will stage another mass protest to prevent contractors demolishing the building. They claim that Fr Moley has alienated everyone and Drumaroad can no longer be called a parish.NEWCASTLE ndash A Newcastle woman has received a prestigious recognition for her behind the scenes contribution to local government.Claire Keenan, was awarded the William Johnston Local Government Employee of the Year Award , for her dedicated work as Executive Assistant to the chief executive of Down Council, John McGrillen, and secretary to the council chairman, Albert Colmer.Claire, who has been working for the council for  years, was awarded her accolade at a presentation in Cookstown last Wednesday.The award, which is run under the Auspices of the Armagh and City District Council, was set up as a memorial to the late Councillor William Johnston of Armagh, who was murdered by terrorists in December .DUNDRUM ndash The Water Service has sought to reassure Dundrum residents over higher than normal levels of chlorine in the villagersquos drinking water.Over the past two weeks residents have reported water which smelled signicantly of chlorine to the extent that it tasted unpleasant and left bathrooms smelling strongly of chlorine after toilet flushing.When the problem didnrsquot go away a number of residents contacted the Water Service concerned about the long-term health implications of drinking water with higher than usual chlorine levels.Water Service officials have admitted that chlorine levels in Dundrum were higher than normal but have given assurances the levels were well within acceptable health guidelines.The problem occurred after the Water Service replaced chlorination equipment at the Dundrum service reservoir on the Kilmegan Road. It has taken engineers some time to accurately adjust the new equipment so chlorine levels have been fluctuating.DOWNPATRICK ndash Controversial plans to pedestrianise part of Downpatrick town centre topped the agenda at a meeting of local traders on Thursday night.The Roads Service is planning to pedestrianise the town centre entrance to the Market Street car park to coincide with the opening of the St Patrickrsquos Centre, much to the anger of nearby traders.At a meeting of the local branch of the Federation of Small Businesses on Thursday evening, traders said the proposal would deter shoppers from the vicinity.One local businessman warned that the removal of parking facilities from the area facing his shop, would be a death knell for local traders.TYRELLA ndash A swt-footed Tyrella man plans to run the London and New York Marathons to raise money for charity.Tony Hammond, an operations manager at Forestside Shopping Centre, near Carryduff, has never run a marathon before, but now hersquos hoping to run two in a bid to raise money for the Get Kids Going charity.The  year-old is participating in a number of fundraising events at Forestside which include abseiling from the roof of the centre and a sponsored fancy dress aerobics.Get Kids Going offers disabled children and young people under  the opportunity to participate in sport.The charity supports them with their sports, training, physiotherapy, travel, design and development of sports wheelchairs.DARRAGH CROSS ndash Community spirit has been revived in Darragh Cross since the establishment of the local community association early last year.Members of the association have worked in recent months to establish a programme of events suitable for people of all ages.With the assistance of a grant of pound, from the Down District Partnership Board, they have also staged a clean up of the local hall.Floors of the hall have been sanded and the car park has been clared, paving the way for local people who want to make the most of the new classes on offer.With football coaching, first aid training and box aerobics classes, the association has lived up to its word and helped provide a core for the community.PORTAFERRY ndash The Eastern Health Board has appointed a Portaferry man as its new chairman.Mr David Russell has taken over the reins from acting chairman Mr Dan McGuinness and will be in the post for four years, during which time he promises to be committed to ldquoopenness, co-operation and inclusiveness.His appointment comes after a distinguished career in the commercial sector and Mr Russell is the Eastern Boardrsquos seventh chairman since its creation in .KILLYLEAGH ndash Killyleagh YCrsquos Irish Cup run came to a crushing end when they were beaten - by Glenavon in a sixth round replay at Mourneview Park on Monday night.Despite the defeat, the glory remains with Dee Heron and his cup battlers, who yet again enhanced their reputation.Killyleagh stunned the whole of football last Tuesday night when they held Glenavon to a - draw.They took the lead with a Mark Holland goal direct from a free kick and almost pulled off another giant-killing act before being pegged back in the dying minutes.Monday nightrsquos replay was a dferent matter altogether as Glenavon capitalised on the absence of Colin Murray and Neil Young through suspension and Glenn OrsquoNeill, who was suffering from a hip injury..prettyPhoto

title: Hopes for funding on Gateway project
story: THE impact that a proposed multi-million pound project in Newcastle could have on helping boost tourism post-Covid was highlighted during a key meeting last week.The flagship Mournes Gateway proposal is a series of ambitious projects, which includes a gondola ride into the Mourne mountains.The proposal is one of several hoping to secure money under the Belfast City Regional Deal, with the Gateway project designed to signicantly enhance future tourist provision in Newcastle and the surrounding area.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is one of six partners working under the city deal umbrella which are are hoping for a share of a near poundbn investment package.City Deals are designed to allow councils to take charge and responsibility of decisions that affect their area, do what they think is best to help businesses grow, create economic growth and decide how public money should be spent.Last May, the NI Executive confirmed that it is providing match funding of poundm with the local authority hoping to secure poundm from this funding pot, with plans to add poundm of ratepayersrsquo money to fund the proposed gondola ride and visitor centre at the old quarry at Thomasrsquo Mountain.Council officials are also working alongside Tourism NI to secure financial backing for other aspects of the tourism initiative which includes an Alpine coaster ride enabling people to hurtle down the side of the mountain on a single track in a buggy.Other aspects of the tourism scheme include an elevated tree top walk in Tollymore Forest Park, a new visitor centre and bird hide at Murlough Nature Reserve and a new bridge constructed under the main Kilkeel Road at the Bloody Bridge.There are also proposals to reduce the the tree line in Donard Forest on the slopes of the Mournes and the development of a so-called green travel network which would allow visitors to hire bicycles and electric bikes to make their way round ious attractions.Council officials say the city deal is ldquocritical to the future recovery of the region and has the potential to stimulate and unlock private investment in the local area. The local authority is also progressing the proposed southern relief road in Newry via the innovative funding package.Last weekrsquos meeting of city deal partners examined how tourism and regeneration elements of the transformative programme of regional investment will help drive economic recovery from the impact of Covid-, as plans for the deal near completion.The event was hosted by Newry, Mourne and Down Council, with members from six partner councils meeting virtually to be updated on the outline business cases for  projects that have now been prepared for the ambitious poundbn programme of investment in innovation and digital, tourism and regeneration, infrastructure and employability and skills.Slieve Gullion councillor Pete Byrne said City Deal partner councils, Queenrsquos and Ulster universities and regional further education colleges had from the outset focused on driving sustained, long term regional growth.ldquoWe have now examined all of our plans through the lens of the Covid- pandemic and wersquore confident that the delivery of our projects will contribute to the long-term recovery of the region, he said.ldquoIt is therefore crucial that we continue to work at pace with all our partners in government and industry to progress a deal that will allow the combined government investment of poundmillion to start to flow into the region in .Cllr Byrne said last weekrsquos meeting focused on plans to ldquoreimagine town and city centres, enhance the regionrsquos attractiveness as a global destination and encourage visitors to stay longer and spend more by creating internationally visible tourism products.He added: ldquoWhen international visitors are ready to travel again, we want to ensure that the Belfast Region is right at the top of their lsquomust seersquo list.In addition to planned investment of more than poundm in tourism and regeneration mdash which will support in the region of , jobs mdash the City Deal aims to harness the potential of the regionrsquos most resilient sectors including le and health sciences, the digital and creative industries and advanced manufacturing, as well as delivering critical digital innovation and skills capability to achieve inclusive economic growth.With the NI Executiversquos commitment of poundm to match-fund the UK governmentrsquos poundm contribution, the overall investment package from both governments and city deal partners, including the local council, currently stands at poundm for the transformative -year programme..prettyPhoto

title: IFA appoint Crossgar man to referee role
story: CROSSGARrsquoS Steven Keenan has been appointed as an independent member of the Irish FArsquos Refereesrsquo Committee.The  year old former Kilmore Rec and Drumaness Mills goalkeeper has worked with the IFA for the last four years.He was delighted to be able to take up this latest opportunity with the local gamersquos governing body.ldquoIrsquove been working with the Irish FA for the last while now, and this time they were looking for people who had a legal and governance background who may be interested in taking on committee roles, said Steven who works as a solicitor.ldquoI was always very keen on remaining involved in the football after I finished my own playing days, but to be honest coaching was never really something that appealed to me.ldquoThis role I thought would suit me well because of the type of work I do. It is progression for me too within the game which is great.Steven said the part that referees play in the game is hugely important, but not necessarily one that others in the game perhaps think too much about.ldquoI think a lot of people just see the referees getting shouted at and that is as much as sometimes they think about it, he continued. The governing bodies are trying to do a lot but in terms of making their role more understood.ldquoI sit on the committee purely from a governance point of view. Ultimatelythere are issues which arise, that will be dealt with by FIFA or UEFA.ldquoCertainly but it has been a useful role for me. It can be similar to the roles I carry out during my day-to-day work. But it is good to see the work being done with junior referees in the game here.He added: The associations try to give them a development plan from working on tournaments like the Champions Youth League, the Champions and Europa League qualiers. There is more spotlight now on referees in the game than ever before, and they have their own fitness programmes and the like of that.ldquoThis role but is giving me an idea of how I can keep myself involved in the game in my post-playing days now..prettyPhoto

title: Lidl unveils plans for new £65m store in Carryduff
story: SUPERMARKET giant Lidl has unveiled its plan for a new pound.m store in Carryduff that will create  new jobs.The new , sq ft outlet is being built at the Carryduff Shopping Centre and in addition to the new jobs, the investment will support  indirect jobs through the development and construction phases.The opening of the new store forms a major part of the shopping centrersquos regeneration after it lay derelict for more than five years.Lidl says the new store store will reflect the retailerrsquos lsquoconceptrsquo design, boasting a high-quality shopping environment with spacious, wide aisles, long tills, restrooms and baby-changing facilities, a delicious bakery offering and beautully designed staff facilities. The store will also benefit from an extensive -space car park.Lidl Northern Irelandrsquos regional property executive, Christopher Speers, says the company is delighted to share its proposed store plans for the new Carryduff store.He said that since confirming its purchase of the site in October last year, Lidl is pleased that this is now a highly anticipated project set to revitalise an important shopping area in the heart of the town.ldquoAs the fastest-growing supermarket in Northern Ireland, this new site will bring signicant investment to the local area and the whole development will create up to  new jobs once complete, he continued.Mr Speers added: ldquoWe look forward to bringing high quality, award-winning produce at exceptional value to the community in due course.News of the Carryduff investment comes after it was confirmed that Down District is set for a jobs boost after the supermarket giant announced plans to recruit more than  new staff province-wide this year.The posts will be created at the companyrsquos  stores across Northern Ireland, including those in Downpatrick, Newcastle and Ballynahinch.Lidl is also creating additional jobs at its distribution centre at Nuttrsquos Corner in Co AntrimThe recruitment drive will expand the retailerrsquos workforce to over , staff with news of the jobs coming after Lidl announced a Covid employee bonus worth pound, which will be shared with all staff this year.The company said the bonus is the third to be offered to recognise the efforts of its staff during the pandemic.Twenty new jobs are to be created at Lidlrsquos Co Down stores where staff will share an employee bonus of pound,.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran has welcomed news of the jobs boost, highlighting the key role played by supermarkets during the continuing pandemic, serving local communities.He said Lidl was a key player in the retail sector with its portfolio of Northern Ireland stores contributing around poundm annually to the local economy, employing more than , staff..prettyPhoto

title: Motorists urged to keep vehicles off new cenotaph
story: MOTORISTS in Ballynahinch have been asked to show more respect for the dead of two world wars and other conflicts by not parking at the townrsquos new cenotaph.The appeal has been issued by Rowallane councillor Billy Walker after fresh concerns were raised about cars parking on paving which has been provided at the base of the war memorial at the top of Main Street.He is to raise the issue with roads officials and Newry, Mourne and Down Council and has suggested thatthe problem persists, bollards may have to be provided to stop drivers parking at the cenotaph.Cllr Walker said Royal British Legion officials were concerned at what was happening, explaining that the organisation was part of a major fundraising initiative to replace the old memorial several years ago. Financial support was also provided by the local council.He fears thatthe parking issue is not addressed, cars will damage the base of the cenotaph erected in memory of people from both sides of the community who fought during the two world wars in particular.ldquoThere is simply no excuse for effectively parking on top of the memorial and I would appeal to people to stop. There is a car park in nearby Windmill Street where there are always available spaces, the councillor continued.ldquoThe war memorial should be treated with respect and those parking their cars at this location at the top of Main Street should really know better.Cllr Walker said the PSNI placed cones around the base of the memorial when the parking issue sparked concern several years ago, suggesting thatdrivers continue to park there concrete bollards may have to be provided.ldquoIt is not the case that there are only a few car parking spaces in Ballynahinch town centre, he said.ldquoThere is no excuse for parking at the base of the war memorial and I am appealing to people to please stop and show some respect.ldquoMany people will be alarmed to learn what is happening at a structure erected in memory of many who paid the ultimate sacrice. The new memorial was erected in order that people in Ballynahinch and the surrounding area remember what others did for them.Cllr Walker says he will do all he can to protect the memorial from damage and hopes that people will show more respect.He added: ldquoThere was a major community initiative to deliver a new memorial in Ballynahinch and it is vital that everything is done to protect it for future generations..prettyPhoto

title: Murlough travel miles
story: MURLOUGH AC have completed a January challenge, covering over , miles, to help with motivation and beat the post-Christmas blues.Club member Charisse Poland arranged for ten teams of Murlough members to take on the task of running or walking the most miles in the month.The winning team won a prize for the charity of their choice. The charities chosen were the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team, Air Ambulance NI, and The Pantry foodbank.Murlough members took the challenge on, and completed more miles than they ever thought possible.Some miles were done in fancy dress, or even in the garden. A few members completed marathons, half marathons and some hiked their way through the Mournes.In total the teams completed over , miles during January..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle Glees take to the roads in fundraising bid to repair hall
story: AN innovative fundraising challenge got underway on Monday with members of the Newcastle Glees Musical Society swapping treading the boards for pounding local roads.While the coronavirus has forced the curtain to come down on live performances at the grouprsquos base at the historic Annesley Hall in the resort, members have donned their running and walking gear to raise pound, to carry out much-needed work at the building.They hope that they will be joined on their fundraising crusade by family and friends who will also take to the roads to run, walk or cycle km a day all this month to help generate crucial funding to help maintain and safeguard the Annesley Hall.And the Glees are hopeful that before the end of this year, they will be slipping back into their performance costumes once again to entertain local audiences.The pound, fundraising target has been set to help maintain the safety of the Societyrsquos ancestral home and to carry out a swathe of modications to make the building safe for performers and audiences post-Covid.With almost half the funding target already raised, the Glees are hoping that they will be able to surpass the pound, target which will considerably help ease the bills that they are facing and meet the hallrsquos annual running costs of pound,.As a widespread coronavirus vaccination programme gathers pace, the Society is doing all it can to raise more funds so the stage and aisles will hopefully soon be filled with music and laughter once again.During these extremely dficult times, the Society is not only faced with the task of keeping its own and community presence alive, but also has the extensive responsibility of maintaining its stunning home.The Societyrsquos committee continues to work tirelessly in an attempt to secure the financial support required to enable a safe reopening of the Annesley Hall which, it hopes, will happen before the end of this year, providing everyone associated with the organisation and the local community with a much-needed boost.While some grant aid is available to assist with the costs associated with implementing new safety measures, additional costs such as delivery and installation charges alongside VAT have to be self funded.In addition, due to continuing Covid restrictions, the Annesley Hall will not be able to generate the income it would have done by renting out the building for dance and ballet classes, examinations, group or club meetings, weddings and civil ceremonies.Despite this, the iconic buildingrsquos extensive running costs including maintenance, insurance and rates remain and have to be paid.Society member Suzanne Smyth mdash who came up with the fundraising idea which the group weighed in behind mdash said the it would welcome support from other members, family and friends during the km a day challenge.She has bravely decided to run five kilometres every day in February to help raise crucial funds to preserve the home of what she described as her ldquoextended family.She said: ldquoDuring these exceptionally dficult times, our fabulous Society is currently clinging to survival so peoplersquos support, however big or small, could make all the dference and would be massively appreciated.ldquoThe committee has been working really hard to put a few fundraisers in place with the k a day one of them. This was the easiest one we could do in terms of social distancing, something which people and families could do together safely.Suzanne, who is a keen runner, has been a member of the Glees for many years, starting off with juniors.ldquoAround  people have signed up for the fundraiser to date and we would be delightedothers would come on board to join us, she continued. ldquoPeople have to do something every day, that is why we chose February as it is the shortest month.ldquoWe have set a target of pound, but did not knowthat was unrealistic or not, but are delighted with the support that we have received to date. We only started on Monday and the support from members and families has been unbelievable. Parents of the Junior Glees are also on board andwe pass our target that we be fantastic.The Junior Glees provided a virtual performance before the end of last year which was headed up by Society members Emma Nugent and Emma-Jane McKnight and was warmly received.ldquoOur committee has been working tirelessly to try and put something in place as the Society is under so much pressure as we canrsquot perform. We are responsible for looking after and maintaining the Annesley Hall and have applied for a few grants which we hope will come though, said Suzanne.ldquoLong before we ever get to the stage of starting rehearsing again we have a lot of work to do including providing sanitising stations and temperature check equipment, while all sinks will have to be replaced to include automatic taps. We also have to provide new auditorium seating, which can be wiped down, and hope we can secure grant money to cover these costs.Suzanne said the February fundraiser will be used to cover the hallrsquos day-to-day running and maintenance costs and that every penny raised will be put to good use.She continued: ldquoWe hope that by the end of the year we will be back in the hall. We are going to push as hard as we can to ensure that we can go back and that the required changes have been made and the hall will be ready.ldquoIt is our plan that we will have all the work that is required completed by the end of the summer so we can hit the ground running. That is why we have applied for grants and launched our fundraising initiative.Suzanne said the dream is to have the hall open again and the Glees rehearsing.She added: ldquoWe may even be able to stage concerts that we have pre-prepared before and perform before small audiences but will have to wait and seethere will be restrictions in terms of audience numbers. At this stage, no one knows.ldquoIt would be amazing to have the hall open again and performing in front of audiences and we would like to think we would be performing shows by Christmas,not sooner.Society members, friends or families, including the Gleesrsquo junior company, who wish to take part are asked to contact Suzanne on  .She added: ldquoWe are asking that as many people please take part at their own pace and have friends and family sponsor them or donate what they can.ldquoWe have created a JustGiving page to share on social media s and would ask people to share their photos or maps of their routes each day to raise awareness, posting on their own social media pages and the Glee Singers Facebook page.Anyone wishing to support the Newcastle Glees with their February fundraiser are asked to visit their JustGiving page at https:www.justgiving crowdfunding newcastleglees.prettyPhoto

title: Providing special needs teaching during lockdown
story: A SPECIAL needs teacher has used the lockdown to create a unique woodland play and outdoor classroom for children who benefit from a range of sensory experiences.Judith Riddell is behind the Empowering Little Minds consultancy in Drumaness and is currently working on a one to one basis outdoors with children with special needs, particularly boys and girls with autism.With the help and support of her husband David, Judith has worked since last March to create a unique and stimulating outdoor woodland classroom that was specically designed to provide a tailored approach to each child.Children aged from three up to  can explore a range of sensory activities on Judithrsquos private woodland and find out what helps them calm down and get to a place where they are able to learn and interact better.The desire to work one to one with children in an outdoor setting has become more important as the former teacher at Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick adapted her business to suit lockdown restrictions.ldquoI had to mody my whole business since the first lockdown after I had self-funded creating my indoor classroom, explained Judith. ldquoI look on it as a positive spin-off from the lockdown as I was closed for nine months. It was something in the back of my mind to do but lockdown made me do it a lot earlier.She started up her consultancy business just over a year ago and has had to ldquothink outside the box since last March when social distancing became a new norm in the pandemic.ldquoWhen I first started the business, I wanted to empower children and their parents who would get an extra boost of some specialised training from me, she said. ldquoSometimes itrsquos hard for children to get all of their educational needs fully met in school.ldquoWhen I work one to one with them, itrsquos amazing to see their progress, even in such a short space of time. You see them really start to fly once their sensory system calms down and they are ready to take in information.Challenged by how she could still run her business during lockdown, Judith decided to put the eight acres of woodland she and her husband owns around their Crawfordstown Road home to good use.ldquoWe took over one acre and created the woodland classroom which can be accessed by a lot of willow structures that I created myself. Therersquos a massive tree house, things to swing on and climb on for the children to enjoy before they go into the woodland classroom which has everything an indoor classroom would have, she said.ldquoItrsquos actually great for both parents and children as they can listen to the birds and enjoy the woodland while their children are involved in learning activities.Judith has  years of experience of education special needs children after graduating from Cambridge University.ldquoI was always passionate about working with children with special needs and when I came back home I was fortunate enough to start working in Knockevin rather than starting in primary schools which I fully expected to do, said Judith.ldquoAfter a while I went to work in Bahrain to set up a school for special needs children on a three-year contract. I came back home just as things began to kick off in the Arab Spring and ed to work at Knockevin.ldquoI decided to set up my own practice in  as it was time to give some empowerment to parents as well as children. It gave me a chance to work with all aspects of a childrsquos development rather than working with one class for the whole year.Judith specialises in working with children aged -. She is also a training consultant for parents to help them understand their childrenrsquos sensory needs and working with staff from health organisations.Judith explained that while working with children with special needs is more complex and involves eight senses mdash not the five senses that we are all more familiar with mdash it can be very rewarding.ldquoAny child whorsquos born does not come with a training book, said Judith. ldquoSpecial needs children have very specic needs and you need to be able to read them in order to cater for that need.ldquoWith the coaching style I use, itrsquos about empowering parents to understand which sensory need their child needs to be fulfilled. With special needs children, you have to fill up with their sensory cup with all eight senses before they can start to learn, When the three extra senses are stimulated, they can be super-calming for everyone but particularly for children who canrsquot communicate their needs.ldquoWhen I coach parents, I explain about the three other senses, and tell what Irsquom doing and why Irsquom doing it to calm their child so that they then can keep using the same strategies at home. As the child learns to self-regulate more, the strategies change and the child is helped along the way.Despite having the space to accommodate more children after lockdown and when group activities are allowed again, Judith is focussed in developing her consultancy with the child always in mind.ldquoThe whole essence of the business is that it does not become a massive enterprise, she stressed.ldquoItrsquos about providing a more quiet, intimate area for the children so that they can feel safe and secure and itrsquos not overly busy. While I can expand and offer more sessions as the days gets longer, the woodland classroom will never be too busy.For further information visit www.empoweringlittleminds..prettyPhoto

title: Royal County Down comes out top
story: ROYAL County Down has been recognised as the most picturesque golf course in the world.The famed Newcastle links came out on top of a study by the Surprise Shop website, which looked at  of the most stunning courses from around the world.The  found that Royal County Down was the subject of , Instagram posts. That left it well ahead of the second-placed Augusta National, home of the Masters, which was the subject of , posts.Itrsquos the latest in a long list of accolades for Royal County Down, which had regularly been voted among the top ten courses in the world.With its unique golfing challenge and stunning views of the Mournes and the Irish Sea, It has played host to many championships and other prestigious events, including the Irish Open, Senior British Open and the Walker CupThe club has evolved markedly since its foundation in . The development of a railway line between Belfast and Newcastle, and the emergence of the town as a seaside resort led to almost instant popularlity.However, the current -hole layout has changed little since it was designed by Old Tom Morris for what was said at the time to be ldquoa sum not to exceed pound.In , the th and th holes were strengthened considerably and in  a new par four th hole.The clubhouse too has evolved from the original building of , which still survives as an integral part of todayrsquos clubhouse, through a number of later extensions and culminating in the refurbishment and extension of . The club now houses a wonderful building.Many famous names have graced its fairways, including Tiger Woods and Rory McIlroy, as well as Tom Watson, Arnold Palmer, Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus..prettyPhoto

title: Spa Wells group donates gifts to local residents
story: MEMBERS of Spa Wells Cultural Association distributed  small care packs to people in the surrounding area on Saturday.With funding left over from the Christmas tree switch-on, which did not happen owing to Covid restrictions, they thought it was still necessary to do something for the community.They decided to make up small care pack bags with a number of food and hygiene items.These were then distributed to people unable to leave their homes, with the hope of lting their spirits in some small way.Residents were pleased to receive the gts and grateful they had been thought off in these dficult days.Spa Wells Cultural Association would like to thank Newry, Mourne and Down Council for their assistance in this venture..prettyPhoto

title: Upgrade needed at Loughinisland road
story: ROADS officials have been asked to invest more money in Loughinisland amid claims that the area is being overlooked by the Department for Infrastructure.Slieve Croob councillor Cathy Mason says there is major concern that the village mdash which is being used as an unofficial bypass by some drivers mdash is being forgotten about.She said the village requires a ldquoserious facelt confirming that residentsrsquo concerns have been raised with Stormont roads minister Nichola Mallon.She said it was ldquodisgraceful that the Loughinisland Road, which is the main road through the village, is being used by drivers as an unofficial bypass and ldquohas basically been left to wreck and ruin.She said so-called speed cushions are no longer fit-for-purpose, also expressing concern about the poor state of the Loughinisland Road.ldquoI have repeatedly requested for resurfacing work to be carried out alongside repairs but the seasons continue to pass with no joy, said Cllr Mason.ldquoThere is a dangerous stretch of road that passes Loughinisland lake which requires urgent attention in terms of a safety barrier to separate the road from the waterrsquos edge. It is nothing short of a miracle that there hasnrsquot been a serious incident here.She said it was clear there had been an increase in traffic using the Loughinisland Road, in particular, heavy vehicles.ldquoMany young families reside in the centre of the village where children play regularly in the estates and green spaces. However, the street lighting also leaves a lot to be desired along this particular stretch stretch, confirmed Cllr Mason.ldquoI have called on roads officials to upgrade the existing lighting to the new LED system as well as assessing the area for new lighting requirements.Cllr Mason expressed concern that the Department of Infrastructure has handed back unspent money to the Treasury, branding the move as ldquosimply unacceptable when a relatively small amount would make huge improvements in Loughinisland and perhaps even delivering a much-needed footpath to safely connect the village to the only local shop and bus stops.She added: ldquoI have written to the government departmentrsquos isional roads manager, while my Sinn Feacutein colleague Emma Rogan MLA has written to Ms Mallon, outlining our concerns about the lack of investment in Loughinisland and the need for money to address key issues..prettyPhoto

quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. title: those us who work services northern ireland face post brexit uncertainty
story: Jim Allister is the voice of unionist grassroots   IRA victim Ann Travers slams Education Authority for appointing ex-bomber Paul KavanaghNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingLocal BuysPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsOpinionThose of us who work in services in Northern Ireland face post Brexit uncertaintyA letter from Neale Weir:By LettersFriday, th February , : am  "       "  "Letter to the editorThis is the opening line of Ulster’s Solemn League and Covenant: “Being convinced in our consciences that Home Rule would be disastrous to the material well-being of Ulster…”It clearly and justly speaks of the importance of material well-being. Not of greed or profligacy but simply an acknowledgement that our daily bread must come from somewhere.    " fill"#ea"  to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Back then Ulster had industries not only to protect but ones that were a cause for envy, a feat made all the more remarkable considering our land’s lack of natural resources in terms of steel and coal. Now, these industries have been replaced by others. Perhaps neither as impressive nor as lucrative as the iron-wroughts of the past but still they are a source of daily bread. However, for people such as myself this source is now at risk. Whomever was tasked with representing Northern Ireland’s interests at the Brexit trade talks saw fit to acquiesce in Northern Ireland’s removal from the single market for services. In layman’s terms this means that contractors, freelancers, specialists and consultants who have their practices based in Northern Irelandare potentially barred from trading in the EU . If this comes to pass then I will have to take my practice out of Northern Ireland and base it in a country that can allow me to work with the EU . Though not immediately apparentit will certainly be felt by those whom manage my affairs in Northern Ireland and of course Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs will no longer be entitled to its percentage of my company’s earnings. This act could be replicated a thousandfold as northern based consultants have to move their admin where. I would ask that those who claim to stand for NI’s best interests go back to the drawing board and see to it that NI can be re-inserted into the single market for services. Rather than being a place that consultants will have to relocate from NI could instead become a place that consultants relocate to, as such a development would not escape the attention of consultants and service providers in GB who find themselves similarly cut off from EU work. Surely it is in our interests to have thousands of companies set up shop in Northern Ireland, pay tax here and utilise local services  There needs to be more examination of the actual consequences of our Brexit arrangements and proposals rather than acting out of blind zeal, which, I fear, has been the guiding hand of too many of those involved. If people find themselves more easily moved by rhetoric and fervour rather than daily bread issues then perhaps they could honourably choose to stand aside in favour of those whose vision is less clouded  Neale Weir, Castledawson, Co Londonderry——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: gifted young larne musician launches debut album during pandemic
story: Jim Allister is the voice of unionist grassroots   IRA victim Ann Travers slams Education Authority for appointing ex-bomber Paul KavanaghNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingLocal BuysPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsPeopleGted young Larne musician launches debut album during pandemicA talented young Larne musician believes it is vitally important for the live concert scene toafter “taking a beating” during the pandemic.By The NewsroomFriday, th February , : pm  "       "  "Conn Thornton.Award-winning jazz and classical pianist Conn Thornton was speaking as he launched his debut album ‘Destroyer’ today .The lead single, ‘City Song’, has already garnered a lot of buzz since its release last month and Conn is determined to build on that foundation.He said: “I’ve played classical recitals countless times over the past few years but I’ve only played live singing gigs a few times before the lockdown happened, so most of my experience with singing live has been on live streamed gigs.    " fill"#ea"  to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...“Once it’s completely safe to do so I will definitely try to secure more gigs because it is vitally important for the live music scene to bounce back as soon as possible after this beating it’s taken over the past year.”It has been a busy time for Conn who after graduating with a degree in Music from Queen’s University Belfast savoured success with his first EP and is now focusing on developing his career.“I had initially planned to start making moves in my music career around the time I graduated from Queen’s last summer but the pandemic just happened to come around as I was just starting out so it was all just an unfortunate coincidence.“The album was intended as a follow-up to my debut EP, last year’s ‘Abraham’s Daughter’, but I intended to flesh out its sound even more and give it a dreamier atmosphere. I would categorise the album’s genre as a kind of mix between indie folk and dream pop. “The title ‘Destroyer’ came from a personal point of view. Depression and mental health is a big theme on the album and intends to allude to the idea of one’s own worst enemy who causes their own problems - your own destroyer.”Abraham’s Daughter was released in May  to much acclaim in the Belfast music scene and Conn also has some classical piano compositions and short film scores under his belt to date.“I take inspiration from a lot of dferent musical styles such as my background in classical and jazz piano, but my main influences now would include David Bowie, Sufjan Stevens, Phoebe Bridgers and Fiona Apple.”For the self-produced album, the versatile former Larne Grammar School pupil had to teach himself how to record, mix and master the audio for its release. “It was completed in just over a month, save for the two tracks recorded in March for the Abraham’s Daughter EP which reappear on this album, which was recorded by my university classmate Lewis Murray.”The experience of playing the piano for nearly two decades - including successes at Larne Music Festival - and performing at classical concerts across Northern Ireland should also stand Conn in good stead as he pursues his dream during the pandemic.---Click here to read: Larne musician’s new stage show for when the curtains go back up.--Thank you for reading this article. story: Jim Allister is the voice of unionist grassroots   LIVE UPDATES: Brexit NI - Staff at Larne and Belfast portsto work after safety concerns - Arlene Foster’s NI Protocol petition hits , and counting - Winner of ‘The Apprentice’ signs DUP NI Protocol petitionNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingLocal BuysPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsBrandon Lewis silent as PM’s ex-law chief says ministers misled the public over Irish Sea borderBrandon Lewis has refused to belatedly accept the Irish Sea border is real – even after the government’s former chief legal adviser spoke out to say ministers had misled the people of Northern Ireland about the new trade frontier.By Sam McBrideFriday, th February , : pm  "       "  "Despite his government spending £m to build ‘border control posts’ at Belfast, Larne and Warrenpoint ports, Brandon Lewis says there is no border. Photo: Charles McQuillan GettyEven after agreeing in writing that there would be a customs and regulatory border between Great Britain and Northern Ireland in , Boris Johnson repeatedly denied that fact.In recent weeks Secretary of State Brandon Lewis – who in a Lucid Talk poll was said to be doing a good or a great job by % of respondents – has again insisted “there is no Irish Sea border” despite a mountain of evidence to the contrary, including his own government’s erection of what it describes as ‘border control posts’.Sir Jonathan Jones, who until five months ago was the Treasury Solicitor and head of the Government Legal Service, said that it had been “obvious” that what had been agreed by Mr Johnson and the EU would disrupt existing trade routes within the UK. Please try again later.Submitting...“It always seemed obvious, at least to me, that there was going to be a border in the Irish Sea,” he said.Speaking on Times Radio, he said: “There has been a problem with people not being honest, or people [not] understanding what the consequence of the new agreements was going to be. It’s obviously feeding this public and political concern with the agreement.”When askedhe blamed ministers for that, he said: “Ministers, politicians generally. “I don’t know whether that was deliberate or whether it was wishful thinking or whether it’s people not understanding the full implications of what was being agreed.”Sir Jonathan, who resigned over the Prime Minister’s moves towards breaking international law “in a limited and specic way”, urged ministers not to make the same mistake again.“The idea that as soon as the going gets tough we threatened to tear up the agreement that we’ve only just recently reached or endorsed would be wrong in principle and a breach of international law,” he said.“It would seem to me to completely undermine any notion of trust and confidence in the UK as a trading partner, whether with the EU or with anybody .
